L. 109–280, title XII</span>, § 1219(d), <span itemtype="date" date="2006-08-17">Aug. 17, 2006</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/120/1085">120 Stat. 1085</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/114/113/dQ/tIV">Pub. L. 114–113, div. Q, title IV</span>, § 410, <span itemtype="date" date="2015-12-18">Dec. 18, 2015</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/129/3121">129 Stat. 3121</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fa2db96-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331"><span itemtype="num" value="331">§ 331.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Reports</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fa2db97-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Secretary of the Treasury shall submit to Congress each year an annual report. The report shall include—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2db98-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> a statement of the public receipts and public expenditures for the prior fiscal year;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2db99-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> estimates of public receipts and public expenditures for the current and next fiscal years;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2db9a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/a/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> plans for improving and increasing public receipts to provide Congress with information on ways to raise amounts necessary to meet public expenditures;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2db9b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/a/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> a statement of all contracts for supplies or services made by the Secretary during the prior fiscal year;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2db9c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/a/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span></p> a statement of appropriations expended to pay for miscellaneous claims not otherwise provided for;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2db9d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/a/6"><span itemtype="num" value="6">(6)</span></p> a statement on all payments made from the fund under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s3126"/>section 3126 of this title for the prior fiscal year; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2db9e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/a/7"><span itemtype="num" value="7">(7)</span></p> estimates of amounts for payment under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s1322/b"/>section 1322(b) of this title.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fa2db9f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fa2dba0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> On the first day of each regular session of Congress, the Secretary shall submit to Congress a report for the prior fiscal year on—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dba1-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/b/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> the total and individual amounts of contingent liabilities and unfunded liabilities of the United States Government;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dba2-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/b/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> as far as practicable, trust fund liabilities, liabilities of Government corporations, indirect liabilities not included as a part of the public debt, and liabilities of insurance and annuity programs (including their actuarial status);<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dba3-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/b/1/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> collateral pledged and assets available (or to be realized) as security for the liabilities (separately noting Government obligations) and other assets specifically available to liquidate the liabilities of the Government; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dba4-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/b/1/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> the total amount in each category under clauses (A)–(C) of this paragraph for each agency.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fa2dba5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> The report shall present the information required under paragraph (1) of this subsection in a concise way, with explanatory material (including an analysis of the significance of liabilities based on past experience and probable risk) the Secretary considers desirable.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fa2dba6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p> On the first day of each regular session of Congress, the Secretary shall submit to Congress a report for the prior fiscal year on the total amount of public receipts and public expenditures listing receipts, when practicable, by ports, districts, and States and the expenditures by each appropriation.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fa2dba7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/d"><span itemtype="num" value="d">(d)</span></p> The Secretary shall report to either House of Congress in person or in writing, as required, on matters referred to the Secretary by that House of Congress.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fa2dba8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/e"><span itemtype="num" value="e">(e)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fa2dba9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/e/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> Not later than March 31 of 1998 and each year thereafter, the Secretary of the Treasury, in coordination with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, shall annually prepare and submit to the President and the Congress an audited financial statement for the preceding fiscal year, covering all accounts and associated activities of the executive branch of the United States Government. The financial statement shall reflect the overall financial position, including assets and liabilities, and results of operations of the executive branch of the United States Government, and shall be prepared in accordance with the form and content requirements set forth by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fa2dbaa-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s331/e/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> The Comptroller General of the United States shall audit the financial statement required by this section.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/884">96 Stat. 884</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/103/356/tIV">Pub. L. 103–356, title IV</span>, § 405(c), <span itemtype="date" date="1994-10-13">Oct. 13, 1994</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/108/3416">108 Stat. 3416</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fa2dbb0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332"><span itemtype="num" value="332">§ 332.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Miscellaneous administrative authority</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0"/>The Secretary of the Treasury may to the extent provided in advance by appropriation Acts—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbb1-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> contract for the temporary or intermittent services of experts or consultants as authorized by <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t5/s3109"/>section 3109 of title 5, United States Code, at rates not to exceed the per diem equivalent to the rate for GS–18;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbb2-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> contract with and reimburse the Department of State for health and medical services for employees of the Department of the Treasury and their dependents serving in foreign countries;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbb3-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> provide for official functions, and reception and representation activities;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbb4-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> maintain, repair, and clean uniforms furnished by the Department of the Treasury to uniformed employees;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbb5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span></p> provide athletic and related activities for students at the Federal Law Enforcement Training Center, Glynco, Georgia;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbb6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332/6"><span itemtype="num" value="6">(6)</span></p> install and maintain fencing, lighting, guard booths, and other facilities as necessary for the performance of protective functions of the Department of the Treasury on property not owned by or under jurisdiction and control of the United States Government and, subsequently, to remove the facilities therefrom;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbb7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332/7"><span itemtype="num" value="7">(7)</span></p> enter into reciprocal assistance agreements with State and local law enforcement agencies and, in connection with the agreements and otherwise, train employees of those agencies, when necessary, with or without reimbursement;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbb8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332/8"><span itemtype="num" value="8">(8)</span></p> provide laboratory assistance to State and local law enforcement agencies, with or without reimbursement;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbb9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332/9"><span itemtype="num" value="9">(9)</span></p> obtain insurance for official motor vehicles operated in foreign countries; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbba-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332/10"><span itemtype="num" value="10">(10)</span></p><p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbbb-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332/10/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> when necessary for the performance of official business—<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fa2dbbc-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332/10/A/i"><span itemtype="num" value="i">(i)</span></p> acquire in foreign countries real property by lease for periods not greater than 10 years and personal property for use in foreign countries by purchase, lease, or otherwise, and<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fa2dbbd-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332/10/A/ii"><span itemtype="num" value="ii">(ii)</span></p> manage, maintain, repair, improve, and insure by purchase of commercial insurance policies properties referred to in clause (i), and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbbe-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s332/10/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> when appropriate, dispose of (by sale, rent, transfer, or otherwise) properties referred to in subparagraph (A)(i).<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/98/302">Pub. L. 98–302</span>, § 3(a), <span itemtype="date" date="1984-05-25">May 25, 1984</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/98/217">98 Stat. 217</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fa2dbc3-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333"><span itemtype="num" value="333">§ 333.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Prohibition of misuse of Department of the Treasury names, symbols, etc.</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fa2dbc4-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">General Rule</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>No person may use, in connection with, or as a part of, any advertisement, solicitation, business activity, or product, whether alone or with other words, letters, symbols, or emblems—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbc5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> the words “Department of the Treasury”, or the name of any service, bureau, office, or other subdivision of the Department of the Treasury,<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbc6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> the titles “Secretary of the Treasury” or “Treasurer of the United States” or the title of any other officer or employee of the Department of the Treasury,<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbc7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/a/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> the abbreviations or initials of any entity referred to in paragraph (1),<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbc8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/a/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> the words “United States Savings Bond” or the name of any other obligation issued by the Department of the Treasury,<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbc9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/a/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span></p> any symbol or emblem of an entity referred to in paragraph (1) (including the design of any envelope or stationary used by such an entity), and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbca-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/a/6"><span itemtype="num" value="6">(6)</span></p> any colorable imitation of any such words, titles, abbreviations, initials, symbols, or emblems,<p itemtype="continuation" style="-uslm-lc:I10" class="indent0 firstIndent0"/>in a manner which could reasonably be interpreted or construed as conveying the false impression that such advertisement, solicitation, business activity, or product is in any manner approved, endorsed, sponsored, or authorized by, or associated with, the Department of the Treasury or any entity referred to in paragraph (1) or any officer or employee thereof.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fa2dbcb-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Treatment of Disclaimers</span>.—</span></p>Any determination of whether a person has violated the provisions of subsection (a) shall be made without regard to any use of a disclaimer of affiliation with the United States Government or any particular agency or instrumentality thereof.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fa2dbcc-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Civil Penalty.—</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbcd-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/c/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">In general</span>.—</span></p>The Secretary of the Treasury may impose a civil penalty on any person who violates the provisions of subsection (a).<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbce-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/c/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Amount of penalty</span>.—</span></p>The amount of the civil penalty imposed by paragraph (1) shall not exceed $5,000 for each use of any material in violation of subsection (a). If such use is in a broadcast or telecast, the preceding sentence shall be applied by substituting “$25,000” for “$5,000”.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbcf-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/c/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Time limitations.—</span></p><p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fa2dbd0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/c/3/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Assessments</span>.—</span></p>The Secretary of the Treasury may assess any civil penalty under paragraph (1) at any time before the end of the 3-year period beginning on the date of the violation with respect to which such penalty is imposed.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fa2dbd1-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/c/3/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Civil action</span>.—</span></p>The Secretary of the Treasury may commence a civil action to recover any penalty imposed under this subsection at any time before the end of the 2-year period beginning on the date on which such penalty was assessed.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbd2-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/c/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Coordination with subsection</span> (d).—</span></p>No penalty may be assessed under this subsection with respect to any violation after a criminal proceeding with respect to such violation has been commenced under subsection (d).<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fa2dbd3-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/d"><span itemtype="num" value="d">(d)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Criminal Penalty.—</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbd4-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/d/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">In general</span>.—</span></p>If any person knowingly violates subsection (a), such person shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $10,000 for each such use or imprisoned not more than 1 year, or both. If such use is in a broadcast or telecast, the preceding sentence shall be applied by substituting “$50,000” for “$10,000”.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbd5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/d/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Time limitations</span>.—</span></p>No person may be prosecuted, tried, or punished under paragraph (1) for any violation of subsection (a) unless the indictment is found or the information instituted during the 3-year period beginning on the date of the violation.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fa2dbd6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s333/d/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Coordination with subsection</span> (c).—</span></p>No criminal proceeding may be commenced under this subsection with respect to any violation if a civil penalty has previously been assessed under subsection (c) with respect to such violation.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/103/296/tIII">Pub. L. 103–296, title III</span>, § 312(<span itemtype="i">l</span>)(1), <span itemtype="date" date="1994-08-15">Aug. 15, 1994</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/108/1528">108 Stat. 1528</span>.)</p><p itemtype="chapter" style="-uslm-lc:I81" id="id0fa2dbdb-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/stI/ch5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">CHAPTER 5—</span><span itemtype="heading">OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT AND BUDGET</span></p><p itemtype="subchapter" style="-uslm-lc:I81" id="id0fa2dbdf-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/stI/ch5/schI"><span itemtype="num" value="I">SUBCHAPTER I—</span><span itemtype="heading">ORGANIZATION</span></p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fa2dbe0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s501"><span itemtype="num" value="501">§ 501.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Office of Management and Budget</span></p>
<p itemtype="content" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0">The Office of Management and Budget is an office in the Executive Office of the President.</p>
<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/886">96 Stat. 886</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fac7817-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s502"><span itemtype="num" value="502">§ 502.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Officers</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fac7818-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s502/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p> The head of the Office of Management and Budget is the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The Director is appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate. Under the direction of the President, the Director shall administer the Office.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fac7819-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s502/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Office has a Deputy Director of the Office of Management and Budget, appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate. The Deputy Director—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac781a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s502/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> shall carry out the duties and powers prescribed by the Director; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac781b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s502/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> acts as the Director when the Director is absent or unable to serve or when the office of Director is vacant.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fac781c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s502/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p> The Office has a Deputy Director for Management appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate. The Deputy Director for Management shall be the chief official responsible for financial management in the United States Government.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fac781d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s502/d"><span itemtype="num" value="d">(d)</span></p> The Office has 3 Assistant Directors who shall carry out the duties and powers prescribed by the Director.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fac781e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s502/e"><span itemtype="num" value="e">(e)</span></p> The Office may have not more than 6 additional officers, each of whom is appointed in the competitive service by the Director, with the approval of the President. Each additional officer shall carry out the duties and powers prescribed by the Director. The Director shall specify the title of each additional officer.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fac781f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s502/f"><span itemtype="num" value="f">(f)</span></p> When the Director and Deputy Director are absent or unable to serve or when the offices of Director and Deputy Director are vacant, the President may designate an officer of the Office to act as Director.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/886">96 Stat. 886</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/101/576/tII">Pub. L. 101–576, title II</span>, § 201, <span itemtype="date" date="1990-11-15">Nov. 15, 1990</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/104/2839">104 Stat. 2839</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fac7824-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503"><span itemtype="num" value="503">§ 503.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Functions of Deputy Director for Management</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fac7825-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> Subject to the direction and approval of the Director, the Deputy Director for Management shall establish governmentwide financial management policies for executive agencies and shall perform the following financial management functions:<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7826-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> Perform all functions of the Director, including all functions delegated by the President to the Director, relating to financial management.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7827-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> Provide overall direction and leadership to the executive branch on financial management matters by establishing financial management policies and requirements, and by monitoring the establishment and operation of Federal Government financial management systems.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7828-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> Review agency budget requests for financial management systems and operations, and advise the Director on the resources required to develop and effectively operate and maintain Federal Government financial management systems and to correct major deficiencies in such systems.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7829-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> Review and, where appropriate, recommend to the Director changes to the budget and legislative proposals of agencies to ensure that they are in accordance with financial management plans of the Office of Management and Budget.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac782a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span></p> Monitor the financial execution of the budget in relation to actual expenditures, including timely performance reports.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac782b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a/6"><span itemtype="num" value="6">(6)</span></p> Oversee, periodically review, and make recommendations to heads of agencies on the administrative structure of agencies with respect to their financial management activities.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac782c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a/7"><span itemtype="num" value="7">(7)</span></p> Develop and maintain qualification standards for agency Chief Financial Officers and for agency Deputy Chief Financial Officers appointed under sections 901 and 903, respectively (excluding any officer designated or appointed under section 901(c)).<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac782d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a/8"><span itemtype="num" value="8">(8)</span></p> Provide advice to agency heads with respect to the selection of agency Chief Financial Officers and Deputy Chief Financial Officers (excluding any officer designated or appointed under section 901(c)).<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac782e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a/9"><span itemtype="num" value="9">(9)</span></p> Provide advice to agencies regarding the qualifications, recruitment, performance, and retention of other financial management personnel.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac782f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a/10"><span itemtype="num" value="10">(10)</span></p> Assess the overall adequacy of the professional qualifications and capabilities of financial management staffs throughout the Government and make recommendations on ways to correct problems which impair the capacity of those staffs.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7830-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a/11"><span itemtype="num" value="11">(11)</span></p> Settle differences that arise among agencies regarding the implementation of financial management policies.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7831-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a/12"><span itemtype="num" value="12">(12)</span></p> Chair the Chief Financial Officers Council established by section 302 of the Chief Financial Officers Act of 1990.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7832-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a/13"><span itemtype="num" value="13">(13)</span></p> Communicate with the financial officers of State and local governments, and foster the exchange with those officers of information concerning financial management standards, techniques, and processes.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7833-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/a/14"><span itemtype="num" value="14">(14)</span></p> Issue such other policies and directives as may be necessary to carry out this section, and perform any other function prescribed by the Director.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fac7834-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> Subject to the direction and approval of the Director, the Deputy Director for Management shall establish general management policies for executive agencies and perform the following general management functions:<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7835-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> Coordinate and supervise the general management functions of the Office of Management and Budget.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7836-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> Perform all functions of the Director, including all functions delegated by the President to the Director, relating to—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fac7837-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/2/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> managerial systems, including the systematic measurement of performance;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fac7838-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/2/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> procurement policy;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fac7839-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/2/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> grant, cooperative agreement, and assistance management;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fac783a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/2/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> information and statistical policy;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fac783b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/2/E"><span itemtype="num" value="E">(E)</span></p> property management;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fac783c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/2/F"><span itemtype="num" value="F">(F)</span></p> human resources management;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fac783d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/2/G"><span itemtype="num" value="G">(G)</span></p> regulatory affairs; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fac783e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/2/H"><span itemtype="num" value="H">(H)</span></p> other management functions, including organizational studies, long-range planning, program evaluation, productivity improvement, and experimentation and demonstration programs.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac783f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> Provide complete, reliable, and timely information to the President, the Congress, and the public regarding the management activities of the executive branch.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7840-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> Facilitate actions by the Congress and the executive branch to improve the management of Federal Government operations and to remove impediments to effective administration.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7841-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span></p> Chair the Chief Information Officers Council established under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t44/s3603"/>section 3603 of title 44.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7842-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/6"><span itemtype="num" value="6">(6)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> Provide leadership in management innovation, through—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fac7843-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/6/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> experimentation, testing, and demonstration programs; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fac7844-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/6/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> the adoption of modern management concepts and technologies.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7845-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/7"><span itemtype="num" value="7">(7)</span></p> Work with State and local governments to improve and strengthen intergovernmental relations, and provide assistance to such governments with respect to intergovernmental programs and cooperative arrangements.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7846-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/8"><span itemtype="num" value="8">(8)</span></p> Review and, where appropriate, recommend to the Director changes to the budget and legislative proposals of agencies to ensure that they respond to program evaluations by, and are in accordance with general management plans of, the Office of Management and Budget.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7847-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/9"><span itemtype="num" value="9">(9)</span></p> Provide advice to agencies on the qualification, recruitment, performance, and retention of managerial personnel.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7848-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s503/b/10"><span itemtype="num" value="10">(10)</span></p> Perform any other functions prescribed by the Director.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/101/576/tII">Pub. L. 101–576, title II</span>, § 202(b), <span itemtype="date" date="1990-11-15">Nov. 15, 1990</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/104/2839">104 Stat. 2839</span>; amended <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/103/272">Pub. L. 103–272</span>, § 4(f)(1)(B), <span itemtype="date" date="1994-07-05">July 5, 1994</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/108/1361">108 Stat. 1361</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/106/58/tVI">Pub. L. 106–58, title VI</span>, § 638(g), <span itemtype="date" date="1999-09-29">Sept. 29, 1999</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/113/476">113 Stat. 476</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/107/347/tI">Pub. L. 107–347, title I</span>, § 102(b), <span itemtype="date" date="2002-12-17">Dec. 17, 2002</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/116/2910">116 Stat. 2910</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fac7850-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s504"><span itemtype="num" value="504">§ 504.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Office of Federal Financial Management</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fac7851-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s504/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p> There is established in the Office of Management and Budget an office to be known as the “Office of Federal Financial Management”. The Office of Federal Financial Management, under the direction and control of the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, shall carry out the financial management functions listed in <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s503/a"/>section 503(a) of this title.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fac7852-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s504/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> There shall be at the head of the Office of Federal Financial Management a Controller, who shall be appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate. The Controller shall be appointed from among individuals who possess—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7853-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s504/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> demonstrated ability and practical experience in accounting, financial management, and financial systems; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7854-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s504/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> extensive practical experience in financial management in large governmental or business entities.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fac7855-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s504/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p> The Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management shall be the deputy and principal advisor to the Deputy Director for Management in the performance by the Deputy Director for Management of functions described in section 503(a).<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/101/576/tII">Pub. L. 101–576, title II</span>, § 203(a), <span itemtype="date" date="1990-11-15">Nov. 15, 1990</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/104/2841">104 Stat. 2841</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fac7859-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s505"><span itemtype="num" value="505">§ 505.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs</span></p>
<p itemtype="content" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0">The Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, established under <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t44/s3503">section 3503 of title 44</span>, is an office in the Office of Management and Budget.</p>
<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/886">96 Stat. 886</span>, § 503; renumbered § 505, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/101/576/tII">Pub. L. 101–576, title II</span>, § 202(a), <span itemtype="date" date="1990-11-15">Nov. 15, 1990</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/104/2839">104 Stat. 2839</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fac785e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s506"><span itemtype="num" value="506">§ 506.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Office of Federal Procurement Policy</span></p>
<p itemtype="content" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0">The Office of Federal Procurement Policy, established under <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t41/s1101/a">section 1101(a) of title 41</span>, is an office in the Office of Management and Budget.</p>
<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/452">Pub. L. 97–452</span>, § 1(1)(A), <span itemtype="date" date="1983-01-12">Jan. 12, 1983</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/2467">96 Stat. 2467</span>, § 504; renumbered § 506, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/101/576/tII">Pub. L. 101–576, title II</span>, § 202(a), <span itemtype="date" date="1990-11-15">Nov. 15, 1990</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/104/2839">104 Stat. 2839</span>; amended <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/111/350">Pub. L. 111–350</span>, § 5(h)(1), <span itemtype="date" date="2011-01-04">Jan. 4, 2011</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/124/3848">124 Stat. 3848</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fac7863-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s507"><span itemtype="num" value="507">§ 507.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Office of Electronic Government</span></p>
<p itemtype="content" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0">The Office of Electronic Government, established under <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t44/s3602">section 3602 of title 44</span>, is an office in the Office of Management and Budget.</p>
<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/107/347/tI">Pub. L. 107–347, title I</span>, § 102(c)(1), <span itemtype="date" date="2002-12-17">Dec. 17, 2002</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/116/2910">116 Stat. 2910</span>.)</p><p itemtype="subchapter" style="-uslm-lc:I81" id="id0fac7867-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/stI/ch5/schII"><span itemtype="num" value="II">SUBCHAPTER II—</span><span itemtype="heading">ADMINISTRATIVE</span></p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fac7868-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s521"><span itemtype="num" value="521">§ 521.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Employees</span></p>
<p itemtype="content" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0">The Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall appoint and fix the pay of employees of the Office under regulations prescribed by the President.</p>
<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/886">96 Stat. 886</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fac786c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s522"><span itemtype="num" value="522">§ 522.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Necessary expenditures</span></p>
<p itemtype="content" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0">The Director of the Office of Management and Budget may make necessary expenditures for the Office under regulations prescribed by the President.</p>
<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/886">96 Stat. 886</span>.)</p><p itemtype="chapter" style="-uslm-lc:I81" id="id0fac7870-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/stI/ch7"><span itemtype="num" value="7">CHAPTER 7—</span><span itemtype="heading">GOVERNMENT ACCOUNTABILITY OFFICE</span></p><p itemtype="subchapter" style="-uslm-lc:I81" id="id0fac7874-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/stI/ch7/schI"><span itemtype="num" value="I">SUBCHAPTER I—</span><span itemtype="heading">DEFINITIONS AND GENERAL ORGANIZATION</span></p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fac7875-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s701"><span itemtype="num" value="701">§ 701.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Definitions</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0"/>In this chapter—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7876-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s701/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> “agency” includes the District of Columbia government but does not include the legislative branch or the Supreme Court.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fac7877-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s701/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> “appropriations” means appropriated amounts and includes, in appropriate context—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fac7878-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s701/2/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> funds;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fac7879-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s701/2/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> authority to make obligations by contract before appropriations; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fac787a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s701/2/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> other authority making amounts available for obligation or expenditure.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/887">96 Stat. 887</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fac7882-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s702"><span itemtype="num" value="702">§ 702.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Government Accountability Office</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fac7883-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s702/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p> The Government Accountability Office is an instrumentality of the United States Government independent of the executive departments.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fac7884-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s702/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p> The head of the Office is the Comptroller General of the United States. The Office has a Deputy Comptroller General of the United States.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fac7885-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s702/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p> The Comptroller General may adopt a seal for the Office.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/887">96 Stat. 887</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/100/545">Pub. L. 100–545</span>, § 2(b), <span itemtype="date" date="1988-10-28">Oct. 28, 1988</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/102/2729">102 Stat. 2729</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/108/271">Pub. L. 108–271</span>, § 8(b), <span itemtype="date" date="2004-07-07">July 7, 2004</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/118/814">118 Stat. 814</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0faec27d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703"><span itemtype="num" value="703">§ 703.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Comptroller General and Deputy Comptroller General</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec27e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec27f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> The Comptroller General and Deputy Comptroller General are appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec280-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> When a vacancy occurs in the office of Comptroller General or Deputy Comptroller General, a commission is established to recommend individuals to the President for appointment to the vacant office. The commission shall be composed of—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec281-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/a/2/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> the Speaker of the House of Representatives;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec282-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/a/2/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> the President pro tempore of the Senate;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec283-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/a/2/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> the majority and minority leaders of the House of Representatives and the Senate;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec284-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/a/2/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> the chairmen and ranking minority members of the Committee on Governmental Affairs of the Senate and the Committee on Government Operations of the House; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec285-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/a/2/E"><span itemtype="num" value="E">(E)</span></p> when the office of Deputy Comptroller General is vacant, the Comptroller General.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec286-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/a/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> A commission established because of a vacancy in the office of the Comptroller General shall recommend at least 3 individuals. The President may ask the commission to recommend additional individuals.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec287-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p> Except as provided in subsection (e) of this section, the term of the Comptroller General is 15 years. The Comptroller General may not be reappointed. The term of the Deputy Comptroller General expires on the date an individual is appointed Comptroller General. The Deputy Comptroller General may continue to serve until a successor is appointed.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec288-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Deputy Comptroller General—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec289-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/c/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> carries out duties and powers prescribed by the Comptroller General; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec28a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/c/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> acts for the Comptroller General when the Comptroller General is absent or unable to serve or when the office of Comptroller General is vacant.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec28b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/d"><span itemtype="num" value="d">(d)</span></p> The Comptroller General shall designate an officer or employee of the Government Accountability Office to act as Comptroller General when the Comptroller General and Deputy Comptroller General are absent or unable to serve or when the offices of Comptroller General and Deputy Comptroller General are vacant.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec28c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/e"><span itemtype="num" value="e">(e)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec28d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/e/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> A Comptroller General or Deputy Comptroller General may retire after becoming 70 years of age and completing 10 years of service as Comptroller General or Deputy Comptroller General (as the case may be). Either may be removed at any time by—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec28e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/e/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> impeachment; or<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec28f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/e/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> joint resolution of Congress, after notice and an opportunity for a hearing, only for—<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0faec290-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/e/1/B/i"><span itemtype="num" value="i">(i)</span></p> permanent disability;<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0faec291-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/e/1/B/ii"><span itemtype="num" value="ii">(ii)</span></p> inefficiency;<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0faec292-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/e/1/B/iii"><span itemtype="num" value="iii">(iii)</span></p> neglect of duty;<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0faec293-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/e/1/B/iv"><span itemtype="num" value="iv">(iv)</span></p> malfeasance; or<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0faec294-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/e/1/B/v"><span itemtype="num" value="v">(v)</span></p> a felony or conduct involving moral turpitude.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec295-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/e/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> A Comptroller General or Deputy Comptroller General removed from office under paragraph (1) of this subsection may not be reappointed to the office.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec296-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/f"><span itemtype="num" value="f">(f)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The annual rate of basic pay of the—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec297-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/f/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> Comptroller General is equal to the rate for level II of the Executive Schedule; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec298-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s703/f/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> Deputy Comptroller General is equal to the rate for level III of the Executive Schedule.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/888">96 Stat. 888</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/100/426/tII">Pub. L. 100–426, title II</span>, § 201, <span itemtype="date" date="1988-09-09">Sept. 9, 1988</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/102/1599">102 Stat. 1599</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/108/271">Pub. L. 108–271</span>, § 8(b), <span itemtype="date" date="2004-07-07">July 7, 2004</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/118/814">118 Stat. 814</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0faec2a0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s704"><span itemtype="num" value="704">§ 704.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Relationship to other laws</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec2a1-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s704/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p> To the extent applicable, all laws generally related to administering an agency apply to the Comptroller General.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec2a2-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s704/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p> A copy of a record and a transcript from a record or proceeding of the Comptroller General, that the Comptroller General or Deputy Comptroller General certifies under seal, shall be admitted as evidence with the same effect as a copy or transcript referred to in <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t28/s1733"/>section 1733 of title 28.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/889">96 Stat. 889</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0faec2a6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705"><span itemtype="num" value="705">§ 705.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Inspector General for the Government Accountability Office</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec2a7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Establishment of Office</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>There is established an Office of the Inspector General in the Government Accountability Office, to—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2a8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> conduct and supervise audits consistent with generally accepted government auditing standards and investigations relating to the Government Accountability Office;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2a9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> provide leadership and coordination and recommend policies, to promote economy, efficiency, and effectiveness in the Government Accountability Office; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2aa-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/a/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> keep the Comptroller General and Congress fully and currently informed concerning fraud and other serious problems, abuses, and deficiencies relating to the administration of programs and operations of the Government Accountability Office.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec2ab-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Appointment, Supervision, and Removal.—</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2ac-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> The Office of the Inspector General shall be headed by an Inspector General, who shall be appointed by the Comptroller General without regard to political affiliation and solely on the basis of integrity and demonstrated ability in accounting, auditing, financial analysis, law, management analysis, public administration, or investigations. The Inspector General shall report to, and be under the general supervision of, the Comptroller General.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2ad-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> The Inspector General may be removed from office by the Comptroller General. The Comptroller General shall, promptly upon such removal, communicate in writing the reasons for any such removal to each House of Congress.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2ae-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/b/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> The Inspector General shall be paid at an annual rate of pay equal to $5,000 less than the annual rate of pay of the Comptroller General, and may not receive any cash award or bonus, including any award under chapter 45 of title 5.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec2af-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Authority of Inspector General</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>In addition to the authority otherwise provided by this section, the Inspector General, in carrying out the provisions of this section, may—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2b0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/c/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> have access to all records, reports, audits, reviews, documents, papers, recommendations, or other material that relate to programs and operations of the Government Accountability Office;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2b1-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/c/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> make such investigations and reports relating to the administration of the programs and operations of the Government Accountability Office as are, in the judgment of the Inspector General, necessary or desirable;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2b2-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/c/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> request such documents and information as may be necessary for carrying out the duties and responsibilities provided by this section from any Federal agency;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2b3-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/c/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> in the performance of the functions assigned by this section, obtain all information, documents, reports, answers, records, accounts, papers, and other data and documentary evidence from a person not in the United States Government or from a Federal agency, to the same extent and in the same manner as the Comptroller General under the authority and procedures available to the Comptroller General in <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s716"/>section 716 of this title;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2b4-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/c/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span></p> administer to or take from any person an oath, affirmation, or affidavit, whenever necessary in the performance of the functions assigned by this section, which oath, affirmation, or affidavit when administered or taken by or before an employee of the Office of Inspector General designated by the Inspector General shall have the same force and effect as if administered or taken by or before an officer having a seal;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2b5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/c/6"><span itemtype="num" value="6">(6)</span></p> have direct and prompt access to the Comptroller General when necessary for any purpose pertaining to the performance of functions and responsibilities under this section;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2b6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/c/7"><span itemtype="num" value="7">(7)</span></p> report expeditiously to the Attorney General whenever the Inspector General has reasonable grounds to believe there has been a violation of Federal criminal law; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2b7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/c/8"><span itemtype="num" value="8">(8)</span></p> provide copies of all reports to the Audit Advisory Committee of the Government Accountability Office and provide such additional information in connection with such reports as is requested by the Committee.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec2b8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/d"><span itemtype="num" value="d">(d)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Complaints by Employees.—</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2b9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/d/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Inspector General—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0faec2ba-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/d/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> subject to subparagraph (B), may receive, review, and investigate, as the Inspector General considers appropriate, complaints or information from an employee of the Government Accountability Office concerning the possible existence of an activity constituting a violation of any law, rule, or regulation, mismanagement, or a gross waste of funds; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0faec2bb-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/d/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> shall refer complaints or information concerning violations of personnel law, rules, or regulations to established investigative and adjudicative entities of the Government Accountability Office.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2bc-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/d/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> The Inspector General shall not, after receipt of a complaint or information from an employee, disclose the identity of the employee without the consent of the employee, unless the Inspector General determines such disclosure is unavoidable during the course of the investigation.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2bd-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/d/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> Any employee who has authority to take, direct others to take, recommend, or approve any personnel action, shall not, with respect to such authority, take or threaten to take any action against any employee as a reprisal for making a complaint or disclosing information to the Inspector General, unless the complaint was made or the information disclosed with the knowledge that it was false or with willful disregard for its truth or falsity.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec2be-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/e"><span itemtype="num" value="e">(e)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Semiannual Reports</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec2bf-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/e/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Inspector General shall submit semiannual reports summarizing the activities of the Office of the Inspector General to the Comptroller General. Such reports shall include, but need not be limited to—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2c0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/e/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> a summary of each significant report made during the reporting period, including a description of significant problems, abuses, and deficiencies disclosed by such report;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2c1-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/e/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> a description of the recommendations for corrective action made with respect to significant problems, abuses, or deficiencies described pursuant to subparagraph (A);<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2c2-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/e/1/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> a summary of the progress made in implementing such corrective action described pursuant to subparagraph (B); and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2c3-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/e/1/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> information concerning any disagreement the Comptroller General has with a recommendation of the Inspector General.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec2c4-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/e/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> The Comptroller General shall transmit the semiannual reports of the Inspector General, together with any comments the Comptroller General considers appropriate, to Congress within 30 days after receipt of such reports.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec2c5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/f"><span itemtype="num" value="f">(f)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Independence in Carrying Out Duties and Responsibilities</span>.—</span></p>The Comptroller General may not prevent or prohibit the Inspector General from carrying out any of the duties or responsibilities of the Inspector General under this section.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec2c6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/g"><span itemtype="num" value="g">(g)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Authority for Staff.—</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2c7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/g/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">In general</span>.—</span></p>The Inspector General shall select, appoint, and employ (including fixing and adjusting the rates of pay of) such personnel as may be necessary to carry out this section consistent with the provisions of this title governing selections, appointments, and employment (including the fixing and adjusting the rates of pay) in the Government Accountability Office. Such personnel shall be appointed, promoted, and assigned only on the basis of merit and fitness, but without regard to those provisions of title 5 governing appointments and other personnel actions in the competitive service, except that no personnel of the Office may be paid at an annual rate greater than $1,000 less than the annual rate of pay of the Inspector General.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2c8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/g/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Experts and consultants</span>.—</span></p>The Inspector General may procure temporary and intermittent services under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t5/s3109"/>section 3109 of title 5 at rates not to exceed the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule under section 5315 of such title.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2c9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/g/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Independence in appointing staff</span>.—</span></p>No individual may carry out any of the duties or responsibilities of the Office of the Inspector General unless the individual is appointed by the Inspector General, or provides services obtained by the Inspector General, pursuant to this paragraph.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2ca-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/g/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Limitation on program responsibilities</span>.—</span></p>The Inspector General and any individual carrying out any of the duties or responsibilities of the Office of the Inspector General are prohibited from performing any program responsibilities.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec2cb-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/h"><span itemtype="num" value="h">(h)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Office Space</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>The Comptroller General shall provide the Office of the Inspector General—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2cc-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/h/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> appropriate and adequate office space;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2cd-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/h/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> such equipment, office supplies, and communications facilities and services as may be necessary for the operation of the Office of the Inspector General;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2ce-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/h/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> necessary maintenance services for such office space, equipment, office supplies, and communications facilities; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0faec2cf-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/h/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> equipment and facilities located in such office space.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0faec2d0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s705/i"><span itemtype="num" value="i">(i)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Definition</span>.—</span></p>As used in this section, the term “Federal agency” means a department, agency, instrumentality, or unit thereof, of the Federal Government.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/110/323">Pub.
