identification of the agency officials responsible for the achievement of each performance goal, who shall be known as goal leaders;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc44607-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/b/6"><span itemtype="num" value="6">(6)</span></p> establish a balanced set of performance indicators to be used in measuring or assessing progress toward each performance goal, including, as appropriate, customer service, efficiency, output, and outcome indicators;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc44608-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/b/7"><span itemtype="num" value="7">(7)</span></p> provide a basis for comparing actual program results with the established performance goals;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc44609-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/b/8"><span itemtype="num" value="8">(8)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> a description of how the agency will ensure the accuracy and reliability of the data used to measure progress towards its performance goals, including an identification of—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc4460a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/b/8/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> the means to be used to verify and validate measured values;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc4460b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/b/8/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> the sources for the data;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc4460c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/b/8/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> the level of accuracy required for the intended use of the data;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc4460d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/b/8/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> any limitations to the data at the required level of accuracy; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc4460e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/b/8/E"><span itemtype="num" value="E">(E)</span></p> how the agency will compensate for such limitations if needed to reach the required level of accuracy;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc4460f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/b/9"><span itemtype="num" value="9">(9)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> describe major management challenges the agency faces and identify—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc44610-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/b/9/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> planned actions to address such challenges;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc44611-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/b/9/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> performance goals, performance indicators, and milestones to measure progress toward resolving such challenges; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc44612-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/b/9/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> the agency official responsible for resolving such challenges; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc44613-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/b/10"><span itemtype="num" value="10">(10)</span></p> identify low-priority program activities based on an analysis of their contribution to the mission and goals of the agency and include an evidence-based justification for designating a program activity as low priority.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc44614-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Alternative Form</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>If an agency, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, determines that it is not feasible to express the performance goals for a particular program activity in an objective, quantifiable, and measurable form, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget may authorize an alternative form. Such alternative form shall—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc44615-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/c/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> include separate descriptive statements of—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc44616-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/c/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p><p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc44617-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/c/1/A/i"><span itemtype="num" value="i">(i)</span></p> a minimally effective program; and<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc44618-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/c/1/A/ii"><span itemtype="num" value="ii">(ii)</span></p> a successful program; or<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc44619-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/c/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> such alternative as authorized by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, with sufficient precision and in such terms that would allow for an accurate, independent determination of whether the program activity’s performance meets the criteria of the description; or<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc4461a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/c/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> state why it is infeasible or impractical to express a performance goal in any form for the program activity.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc4461b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/d"><span itemtype="num" value="d">(d)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Treatment of Program Activities</span>.—</span></p>For the purpose of complying with this section, an agency may aggregate, disaggregate, or consolidate program activities, except that any aggregation or consolidation may not omit or minimize the significance of any program activity constituting a major function or operation for the agency.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc4461c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/e"><span itemtype="num" value="e">(e)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Appendix</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>An agency may submit with an annual performance plan an appendix covering any portion of the plan that—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc4461d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/e/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> is specifically authorized under criteria established by an Executive order to be kept secret in the interest of national defense or foreign policy; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc4461e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/e/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> is properly classified pursuant to such Executive order.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc4461f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/f"><span itemtype="num" value="f">(f)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Inherently Governmental Functions</span>.—</span></p>The functions and activities of this section shall be considered to be inherently governmental functions. The drafting of performance plans under this section shall be performed only by Federal employees.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc44620-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/g"><span itemtype="num" value="g">(g)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Chief Human Capital Officers</span>.—</span></p>With respect to each agency with a Chief Human Capital Officer, the Chief Human Capital Officer shall prepare that portion of the annual performance plan described under subsection (b)(5)(A).<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc44621-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/h"><span itemtype="num" value="h">(h)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Definitions</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>For purposes of this section and sections 1116 through 1125, and sections 9703 and 9704, the term—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc44622-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/h/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> “agency” has the same meaning as such term is defined under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t5/s306/f"/>section 306(f) of title 5;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc44623-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/h/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> “crosscutting” means across organizational (such as agency) boundaries;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc44624-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/h/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> “customer service measure” means an assessment of service delivery to a customer, client, citizen, or other recipient, which can include an assessment of quality, timeliness, and satisfaction among other factors;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc44625-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/h/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> “efficiency measure” means a ratio of a program activity’s inputs (such as costs or hours worked by employees) to its outputs (amount of products or services delivered) or outcomes (the desired results of a program);<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc44626-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/h/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span></p> “major management challenge” means programs or management functions, within or across agencies, that have greater vulnerability to waste, fraud, abuse, and mismanagement (such as issues identified by the Government Accountability Office as high risk or issues identified by an Inspector General) where a failure to perform well could seriously affect the ability of an agency or the Government to achieve its mission or goals;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc44627-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/h/6"><span itemtype="num" value="6">(6)</span></p> “milestone” means a scheduled event signifying the completion of a major deliverable or a set of related deliverables or a phase of work;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc44628-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/h/7"><span itemtype="num" value="7">(7)</span></p> “outcome measure” means an assessment of the results of a program activity compared to its intended purpose;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc44629-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/h/8"><span itemtype="num" value="8">(8)</span></p> “output measure” means the tabulation, calculation, or recording of activity or effort that can be expressed in a quantitative or qualitative manner;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc4462a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/h/9"><span itemtype="num" value="9">(9)</span></p> “performance goal” means a target level of performance expressed as a tangible, measurable objective, against which actual achievement can be compared, including a goal expressed as a quantitative standard, value, or rate;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc4462b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/h/10"><span itemtype="num" value="10">(10)</span></p> “performance indicator” means a particular value or characteristic used to measure output or outcome;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc4462c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/h/11"><span itemtype="num" value="11">(11)</span></p> “program activity” means a specific activity or project as listed in the program and financing schedules of the annual budget of the United States Government; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc4462d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1115/h/12"><span itemtype="num" value="12">(12)</span></p> “program evaluation” means an assessment, through objective measurement and systematic analysis, of the manner and extent to which Federal programs achieve intended objectives.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/111/352">Pub. L. 111–352</span>, § 3, <span itemtype="date" date="2011-01-04">Jan. 4, 2011</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/124/3867">124 Stat. 3867</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fc69026-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116"><span itemtype="num" value="1116">§ 1116.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Agency performance reporting</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69027-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p> The head of each agency shall make available on a public website of the agency and to the Office of Management and Budget an update on agency performance.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69028-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69029-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> Each update shall compare actual performance achieved with the performance goals established in the agency performance plan under section 1115(b) and shall occur no less than 150 days after the end of each fiscal year, with more frequent updates of actual performance on indicators that provide data of significant value to the Government, Congress, or program partners at a reasonable level of administrative burden.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc6902a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> If performance goals are specified in an alternative form under section 1115(c), the results shall be described in relation to such specifications, including whether the performance failed to meet the criteria of a minimally effective or successful program.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc6902b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> Each update shall—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc6902c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> review the success of achieving the performance goals and include actual results for the 5 preceding fiscal years;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc6902d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> evaluate the performance plan for the current fiscal year relative to the performance achieved toward the performance goals during the period covered by the update;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc6902e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> explain and describe where a performance goal has not been met (including when a program activity’s performance is determined not to have met the criteria of a successful program activity under section 1115(c)(1)(A)(ii) or a corresponding level of achievement if another alternative form is used)—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc6902f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/3/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> why the goal was not met;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69030-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/3/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> those plans and schedules for achieving the established performance goal; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69031-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/3/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> if the performance goal is impractical or infeasible, why that is the case and what action is recommended;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69032-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> describe the use and assess the effectiveness in achieving performance goals of any waiver under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s9703"/>section 9703 of this title;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69033-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span></p> include a review of the performance goals and evaluation of the performance plan relative to the agency’s strategic human capital management;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69034-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/6"><span itemtype="num" value="6">(6)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> describe how the agency ensures the accuracy and reliability of the data used to measure progress towards its performance goals, including an identification of—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69035-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/6/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> the means used to verify and validate measured values;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69036-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/6/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> the sources for the data;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69037-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/6/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> the level of accuracy required for the intended use of the data;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69038-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/6/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> any limitations to the data at the required level of accuracy; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69039-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/6/E"><span itemtype="num" value="E">(E)</span></p> how the agency has compensated for such limitations if needed to reach the required level of accuracy; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc6903a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/c/7"><span itemtype="num" value="7">(7)</span></p> include the summary findings of those program evaluations completed during the period covered by the update.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc6903b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/d"><span itemtype="num" value="d">(d)</span></p> If an agency performance update includes any program activity or information that is specifically authorized under criteria established by an Executive Order to be kept secret in the interest of national defense or foreign policy and is properly classified pursuant to such Executive Order, the head of the agency shall make such information available in the classified appendix provided under section 1115(e).<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc6903c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/e"><span itemtype="num" value="e">(e)</span></p> The functions and activities of this section shall be considered to be inherently governmental functions. The drafting of agency performance updates under this section shall be performed only by Federal employees.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc6903d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/f"><span itemtype="num" value="f">(f)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> Each fiscal year, the Office of Management and Budget shall determine whether the agency programs or activities meet performance goals and objectives outlined in the agency performance plans and submit a report on unmet goals to—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc6903e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/f/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> the head of the agency;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc6903f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/f/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69040-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/f/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> the Committee on Oversight and Governmental Reform of the House of Representatives; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69041-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/f/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> the Government Accountability Office.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69042-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/g"><span itemtype="num" value="g">(g)</span></p> If an agency’s programs or activities have not met performance goals as determined by the Office of Management and Budget for 1 fiscal year, the head of the agency shall submit a performance improvement plan to the Office of Management and Budget to increase program effectiveness for each unmet goal with measurable milestones. The agency shall designate a senior official who shall oversee the performance improvement strategies for each unmet goal.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69043-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/h"><span itemtype="num" value="h">(h)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69044-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/h/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> If the Office of Management and Budget determines that agency programs or activities have unmet performance goals for 2 consecutive fiscal years, the head of the agency shall—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69045-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/h/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> submit to Congress a description of the actions the Administration will take to improve performance, including proposed statutory changes or planned executive actions; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69046-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/h/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> describe any additional funding the agency will obligate to achieve the goal, if such an action is determined appropriate in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, for an amount determined appropriate by the Director.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69047-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/h/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> In providing additional funding described under paragraph (1)(B), the head of the agency shall use any reprogramming or transfer authority available to the agency. If after exercising such authority additional funding is necessary to achieve the level determined appropriate by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, the head of the agency shall submit a request to Congress for additional reprogramming or transfer authority.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69048-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/i"><span itemtype="num" value="i">(i)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> If an agency’s programs or activities have not met performance goals as determined by the Office of Management and Budget for 3 consecutive fiscal years, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall submit recommendations to Congress on actions to improve performance not later than 60 days after that determination, including—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69049-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/i/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> reauthorization proposals for each program or activity that has not met performance goals;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc6904a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/i/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> proposed statutory changes necessary for the program activities to achieve the proposed level of performance on each performance goal; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc6904b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1116/i/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> planned executive actions or identification of the program for termination or reduction in the President’s budget.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/111/352">Pub. L. 111–352</span>, § 4, <span itemtype="date" date="2011-01-04">Jan. 4, 2011</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/124/3871">124 Stat. 3871</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fc69050-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1117"><span itemtype="num" value="1117">§ 1117.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Exemption</span></p>
<p itemtype="content" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0">The Director of the Office of Management and Budget may exempt from the requirements of sections 1115 and 1116 of this title and <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t5/s306">section 306 of title 5</span>, any agency with annual outlays of $20,000,000 or less.</p>
<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/103/62">Pub. L. 103–62</span>, § 4(b), <span itemtype="date" date="1993-08-03">Aug. 3, 1993</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/107/289">107 Stat. 289</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fc69054-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1118"><span itemtype="num" value="1118">§ 1118.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Pilot projects for performance goals</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69055-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1118/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p> The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, after consultation with the head of each agency, shall designate not less than ten agencies as pilot projects in performance measurement for fiscal years 1994, 1995, and 1996. The selected agencies shall reflect a representative range of Government functions and capabilities in measuring and reporting program performance.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69056-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1118/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p> Pilot projects in the designated agencies shall undertake the preparation of performance plans under section 1115, and program performance reports under section 1116, other than section 1116(c), for one or more of the major functions and operations of the agency. A strategic plan shall be used when preparing agency performance plans during one or more years of the pilot period.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69057-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1118/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> No later than <span itemtype="date" date="1997-05-01">May 1, 1997</span>, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall submit a report to the President and to the Congress which shall—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69058-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1118/c/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> assess the benefits, costs, and usefulness of the plans and reports prepared by the pilot agencies in meeting the purposes of the Government Performance and Results Act of 1993;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69059-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1118/c/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> identify any significant difficulties experienced by the pilot agencies in preparing plans and reports; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc6905a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1118/c/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> set forth any recommended changes in the requirements of the provisions of Government Performance and Results Act of 1993, <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t5/s306"/>section 306 of title 5, sections 1105, 1115, 1116, 1117, 1119 and 9703 of this title, and this section.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/103/62">Pub. L. 103–62</span>, § 6(a), <span itemtype="date" date="1993-08-03">Aug. 3, 1993</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/107/290">107 Stat. 290</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fc6905f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1119"><span itemtype="num" value="1119">§ 1119.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Pilot projects for performance budgeting</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69060-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1119/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p> The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, after consultation with the head of each agency shall designate not less than five agencies as pilot projects in performance budgeting for fiscal years 1998 and 1999. At least three of the agencies shall be selected from those designated as pilot projects under section 1118, and shall also reflect a representative range of Government functions and capabilities in measuring and reporting program performance.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69061-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1119/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p> Pilot projects in the designated agencies shall cover the preparation of performance budgets. Such budgets shall present, for one or more of the major functions and operations of the agency, the varying levels of performance, including outcome-related performance, that would result from different budgeted amounts.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69062-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1119/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p> The Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall include, as an alternative budget presentation in the budget submitted under section 1105 for fiscal year 1999, the performance budgets of the designated agencies for this fiscal year.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69063-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1119/d"><span itemtype="num" value="d">(d)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> No later than <span itemtype="date" date="2001-03-31">March 31, 2001</span>, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall transmit a report to the President and to the Congress on the performance budgeting pilot projects which shall—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69064-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1119/d/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> assess the feasibility and advisability of including a performance budget as part of the annual budget submitted under section 1105;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69065-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1119/d/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> describe any difficulties encountered by the pilot agencies in preparing a performance budget;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69066-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1119/d/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> recommend whether legislation requiring performance budgets should be proposed and the general provisions of any legislation; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69067-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1119/d/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> set forth any recommended changes in the other requirements of the Government Performance and Results Act of 1993, <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t5/s306"/>section 306 of title 5, sections 1105, 1115, 1116, 1117, and 9703 of this title, and this section.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69068-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1119/e"><span itemtype="num" value="e">(e)</span></p> After receipt of the report required under subsection (d), the Congress may specify that a performance budget be submitted as part of the annual budget submitted under section 1105.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/103/62">Pub. L. 103–62</span>, § 6(c), <span itemtype="date" date="1993-08-03">Aug. 3, 1993</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/107/291">107 Stat. 291</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fc6906d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120"><span itemtype="num" value="1120">§ 1120.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Federal Government and agency priority goals</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc6906e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Federal Government Priority Goals.—</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc6906f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall coordinate with agencies to develop priority goals to improve the performance and management of the Federal Government. Such Federal Government priority goals shall include—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69070-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> outcome-oriented goals covering a limited number of crosscutting policy areas; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69071-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> goals for management improvements needed across the Federal Government, including—<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I14" class="indent3" id="id0fc69072-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/1/B/i"><span itemtype="num" value="i">(i)</span></p> financial management;<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I14" class="indent3" id="id0fc69073-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/1/B/ii"><span itemtype="num" value="ii">(ii)</span></p> human capital management;<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I14" class="indent3" id="id0fc69074-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/1/B/iii"><span itemtype="num" value="iii">(iii)</span></p> information technology management;<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I14" class="indent3" id="id0fc69075-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/1/B/iv"><span itemtype="num" value="iv">(iv)</span></p> procurement and acquisition management; and<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I14" class="indent3" id="id0fc69076-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/1/B/v"><span itemtype="num" value="v">(v)</span></p> real property management;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69077-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> The Federal Government priority goals shall be long-term in nature. At a minimum, the Federal Government priority goals shall be updated or revised every 4 years and made publicly available concurrently with the submission of the budget of the United States Government made in the first full fiscal year following any year in which the term of the President commences under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t3/s101"/>section 101 of title 3. As needed, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget may make adjustments to the Federal Government priority goals to reflect significant changes in the environment in which the Federal Government is operating, with appropriate notification of Congress.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69078-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> When developing or making adjustments to Federal Government priority goals, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall consult periodically with the Congress, including obtaining majority and minority views from—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69079-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/3/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> the Committees on Appropriations of the Senate and the House of Representatives;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc6907a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/3/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> the Committees on the Budget of the Senate and the House of Representatives;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc6907b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/3/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc6907c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/3/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform of the House of Representatives;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc6907d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/3/E"><span itemtype="num" value="E">(E)</span></p> the Committee on Finance of the Senate;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc6907e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/3/F"><span itemtype="num" value="F">(F)</span></p> the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc6907f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/3/G"><span itemtype="num" value="G">(G)</span></p> any other committees as determined appropriate;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69080-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> The Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall consult with the appropriate committees of Congress at least once every 2 years.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69081-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span></p> The Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall make information about the Federal Government priority goals available on the website described under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s1122"/>section 1122 of this title.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69082-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a/6"><span itemtype="num" value="6">(6)</span></p> The Federal Government performance plan required under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s1115/a"/>section 1115(a) of this title shall be consistent with the Federal Government priority goals.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69083-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Agency Priority Goals.—</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69084-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> Every 2 years, the head of each agency listed in <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s901/b">section 901(b) of this title</span>, or as otherwise determined by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, shall identify agency priority goals from among the performance goals of the agency. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall determine the total number of agency priority goals across the Government, and the number to be developed by each agency. The agency priority goals shall—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69085-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/b/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> reflect the highest priorities of the agency, as determined by the head of the agency and informed by the Federal Government priority goals provided under subsection (a) and the consultations with Congress and other interested parties required by <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t5/s306/d"/>section 306(d) of title 5;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69086-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/b/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> have ambitious targets that can be achieved within a 2-year period;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69087-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/b/1/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> have a clearly identified agency official, known as a goal leader, who is responsible for the achievement of each agency priority goal;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69088-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/b/1/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> have interim quarterly targets for performance indicators if more frequent updates of actual performance provides data of significant value to the Government, Congress, or program partners at a reasonable level of administrative burden; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc69089-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/b/1/E"><span itemtype="num" value="E">(E)</span></p> have clearly defined quarterly milestones.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc6908a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> If an agency priority goal includes any program activity or information that is specifically authorized under criteria established by an Executive order to be kept secret in the interest of national defense or foreign policy and is properly classified pursuant to such Executive order, the head of the agency shall make such information available in the classified appendix provided under section 1115(e).<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc6908b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1120/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p> The functions and activities of this section shall be considered to be inherently governmental functions. The development of Federal Government and agency priority goals shall be performed only by Federal employees.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/111/352">Pub. L. 111–352</span>, § 5, <span itemtype="date" date="2011-01-04">Jan. 4, 2011</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/124/3873">124 Stat. 3873</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fc6908d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1121"><span itemtype="num" value="1121">§ 1121.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Quarterly priority progress reviews and use of performance information</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc6908e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1121/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Use of Performance Information To Achieve Federal Government Priority Goals</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>Not less than quarterly, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, with the support of the Performance Improvement Council, shall—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc6908f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1121/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> for each Federal Government priority goal required by <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a"/>section 1120(a) of this title, review with the appropriate lead Government official the progress achieved during the most recent quarter, overall trend data, and the likelihood of meeting the planned level of performance;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69090-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1121/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> include in such reviews officials from the agencies, organizations, and program activities that contribute to the accomplishment of each Federal Government priority goal;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69091-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1121/a/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> assess whether agencies, organizations, program activities, regulations, tax expenditures, policies, and other activities are contributing as planned to each Federal Government priority goal;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69092-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1121/a/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> categorize the Federal Government priority goals by risk of not achieving the planned level of performance; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69093-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1121/a/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span></p> for the Federal Government priority goals at greatest risk of not meeting the planned level of performance, identify prospects and strategies for performance improvement, including any needed changes to agencies, organizations, program activities, regulations, tax expenditures, policies or other activities.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc69094-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1121/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Agency Use of Performance Information To Achieve Agency Priority Goals</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>Not less than quarterly, at each agency required to develop agency priority goals required by <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s1120/b">section 1120(b) of this title</span>, the head of the agency and Chief Operating Officer, with the support of the agency Performance Improvement Officer, shall—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69095-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1121/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> for each agency priority goal, review with the appropriate goal leader the progress achieved during the most recent quarter, overall trend data, and the likelihood of meeting the planned level of performance;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69096-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1121/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> coordinate with relevant personnel within and outside the agency who contribute to the accomplishment of each agency priority goal;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69097-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1121/b/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> assess whether relevant organizations, program activities, regulations, policies, and other activities are contributing as planned to the agency priority goals;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69098-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1121/b/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> categorize agency priority goals by risk of not achieving the planned level of performance; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc69099-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1121/b/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span></p> for agency priority goals at greatest risk of not meeting the planned level of performance, identify prospects and strategies for performance improvement, including any needed changes to agency program activities, regulations, policies, or other activities.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/111/352">Pub. L. 111–352</span>, § 6, <span itemtype="date" date="2011-01-04">Jan. 4, 2011</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/124/3875">124 Stat. 3875</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fc6909b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122"><span itemtype="num" value="1122">§ 1122.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Transparency of programs, priority goals, and results</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc6909c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Transparency of Agency Programs.—</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc6909d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">In general</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>Not later than <span itemtype="date" date="2012-10-01">October 1, 2012</span>, the Office of Management and Budget shall—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc6909e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/a/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> ensure the effective operation of a single website;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc6909f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/a/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> at a minimum, update the website on a quarterly basis; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690a0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/a/1/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> include on the website information about each program identified by the agencies.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690a1-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Information</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>Information for each program described under paragraph (1) shall include—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690a2-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/a/2/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> an identification of how the agency defines the term “program”, consistent with guidance provided by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, including the program activities that are aggregated, disaggregated, or consolidated to be considered a program by the agency;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690a3-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/a/2/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> a description of the purposes of the program and the contribution of the program to the mission and goals of the agency; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690a4-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/a/2/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> an identification of funding for the current fiscal year and previous 2 fiscal years.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc690a5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Transparency of Agency Priority Goals and Results</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>The head of each agency required to develop agency priority goals shall make information about each agency priority goal available to the Office of Management and Budget for publication on the website, with the exception of any information covered by <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s1120/b/2">section 1120(b)(2) of this title</span>. In addition to an identification of each agency priority goal, the website shall also consolidate information about each agency priority goal, including—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690a6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> a description of how the agency incorporated any views and suggestions obtained through congressional consultations about the agency priority goal;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690a7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> an identification of key factors external to the agency and beyond its control that could significantly affect the achievement of the agency priority goal;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690a8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> a description of how each agency priority goal will be achieved, including—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690a9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/3/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> the strategies and resources required to meet the priority goal;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690aa-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/3/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> clearly defined milestones;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690ab-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/3/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> the organizations, program activities, regulations, policies, and other activities that contribute to each goal, both within and external to the agency;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690ac-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/3/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> how the agency is working with other agencies to achieve the goal; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690ad-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/3/E"><span itemtype="num" value="E">(E)</span></p> an identification of the agency official responsible for achieving the priority goal;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690ae-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> the performance indicators to be used in measuring or assessing progress;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690af-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> a description of how the agency ensures the accuracy and reliability of the data used to measure progress towards the priority goal, including an identification of—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690b0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/5/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> the means used to verify and validate measured values;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690b1-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/5/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> the sources for the data;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690b2-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/5/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> the level of accuracy required for the intended use of the data;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690b3-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/5/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> any limitations to the data at the required level of accuracy; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690b4-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/5/E"><span itemtype="num" value="E">(E)</span></p> how the agency has compensated for such limitations if needed to reach the required level of accuracy;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690b5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/6"><span itemtype="num" value="6">(6)</span></p> the results achieved during the most recent quarter and overall trend data compared to the planned level of performance;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690b6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/7"><span itemtype="num" value="7">(7)</span></p> an assessment of whether relevant organizations, program activities, regulations, policies, and other activities are contributing as planned;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690b7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/8"><span itemtype="num" value="8">(8)</span></p> an identification of the agency priority goals at risk of not achieving the planned level of performance; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690b8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/b/9"><span itemtype="num" value="9">(9)</span></p> any prospects or strategies for performance improvement.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc690b9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Transparency of Federal Government Priority Goals and Results</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>The Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall also make available on the website—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690ba-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/c/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> a brief description of each of the Federal Government priority goals required by <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s1120/a"/>section 1120(a) of this title;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690bb-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/c/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> a description of how the Federal Government priority goals incorporate views and suggestions obtained through congressional consultations;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690bc-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/c/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> the Federal Government performance goals and performance indicators associated with each Federal Government priority goal as required by <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s1115/a"/>section 1115(a) of this title;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690bd-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/c/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> an identification of the lead Government official for each Federal Government performance goal;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690be-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/c/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span></p> the results achieved during the most recent quarter and overall trend data compared to the planned level of performance;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690bf-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/c/6"><span itemtype="num" value="6">(6)</span></p> an identification of the agencies, organizations, program activities, regulations, tax expenditures, policies, and other activities that contribute to each Federal Government priority goal;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690c0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/c/7"><span itemtype="num" value="7">(7)</span></p> an assessment of whether relevant agencies, organizations, program activities, regulations, tax expenditures, policies, and other activities are contributing as planned;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690c1-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/c/8"><span itemtype="num" value="8">(8)</span></p> an identification of the Federal Government priority goals at risk of not achieving the planned level of performance; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690c2-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/c/9"><span itemtype="num" value="9">(9)</span></p> any prospects or strategies for performance improvement.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc690c3-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1122/d"><span itemtype="num" value="d">(d)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Information on Website</span>.—</span></p>The information made available on the website under this section shall be readily accessible and easily found on the Internet by the public and members and committees of Congress. Such information shall also be presented in a searchable, machine-readable format. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall issue guidance to ensure that such information is provided in a way that presents a coherent picture of all Federal programs, and the performance of the Federal Government as well as individual agencies.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/111/352">Pub. L. 111–352</span>, § 7, <span itemtype="date" date="2011-01-04">Jan. 4, 2011</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/124/3876">124 Stat. 3876</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fc690c5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1123"><span itemtype="num" value="1123">§ 1123.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Chief Operating Officers</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc690c6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1123/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Establishment</span>.—</span></p>At each agency, the deputy head of agency, or equivalent, shall be the Chief Operating Officer of the agency.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc690c7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1123/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Function</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>Each Chief Operating Officer shall be responsible for improving the management and performance of the agency, and shall—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690c8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1123/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> provide overall organization management to improve agency performance and achieve the mission and goals of the agency through the use of strategic and performance planning, measurement, analysis, regular assessment of progress, and use of performance information to improve the results achieved;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690c9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1123/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> advise and assist the head of agency in carrying out the requirements of sections 1115 through 1122 of this title and <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t5/s306"/>section 306 of title 5;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690ca-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1123/b/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> oversee agency-specific efforts to improve management functions within the agency and across Government; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690cb-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1123/b/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> coordinate and collaborate with relevant personnel within and external to the agency who have a significant role in contributing to and achieving the mission and goals of the agency, such as the Chief Financial Officer, Chief Human Capital Officer, Chief Acquisition Officer/Senior Procurement Executive, Chief Information Officer, and other line of business chiefs at the agency.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/111/352">Pub. L. 111–352</span>, § 8, <span itemtype="date" date="2011-01-04">Jan. 4, 2011</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/124/3878">124 Stat. 3878</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fc690cd-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124"><span itemtype="num" value="1124">§ 1124.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Performance Improvement Officers and the Performance Improvement Council</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc690ce-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Performance Improvement Officers.—</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690cf-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Establishment</span>.—</span></p>At each agency, the head of the agency, in consultation with the agency Chief Operating Officer, shall designate a senior executive of the agency as the agency Performance Improvement Officer.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690d0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Function</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>Each Performance Improvement Officer shall report directly to the Chief Operating Officer. Subject to the direction of the Chief Operating Officer, each Performance Improvement Officer shall—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690d1-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/a/2/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> advise and assist the head of the agency and the Chief Operating Officer to ensure that the mission and goals of the agency are achieved through strategic and performance planning, measurement, analysis, regular assessment of progress, and use of performance information to improve the results achieved;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690d2-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/a/2/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> advise the head of the agency and the Chief Operating Officer on the selection of agency goals, including opportunities to collaborate with other agencies on common goals;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690d3-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/a/2/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> assist the head of the agency and the Chief Operating Officer in overseeing the implementation of the agency strategic planning, performance planning, and reporting requirements provided under sections 1115 through 1122 of this title and sections 306 of title 5, including the contributions of the agency to the Federal Government priority goals;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690d4-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/a/2/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> support the head of agency and the Chief Operating Officer in the conduct of regular reviews of agency performance, including at least quarterly reviews of progress achieved toward agency priority goals, if applicable;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690d5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/a/2/E"><span itemtype="num" value="E">(E)</span></p> assist the head of the agency and the Chief Operating Officer in the development and use within the agency of performance measures in personnel performance appraisals, and, as appropriate, other agency personnel and planning processes and assessments; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690d6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/a/2/F"><span itemtype="num" value="F">(F)</span></p> ensure that agency progress toward the achievement of all goals is communicated to leaders, managers, and employees in the agency and Congress, and made available on a public website of the agency.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id0fc690d7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Performance Improvement Council.—</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690d8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Establishment</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>There is established a Performance Improvement Council, consisting of—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690d9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, who shall act as chairperson of the Council;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690da-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> the Performance Improvement Officer from each agency defined in <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s901/b"/>section 901(b) of this title;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690db-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/1/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> other Performance Improvement Officers as determined appropriate by the chairperson; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690dc-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/1/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> other individuals as determined appropriate by the chairperson.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc690dd-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Function</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>The Performance Improvement Council shall—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690de-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/2/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> be convened by the chairperson or the designee of the chairperson, who shall preside at the meetings of the Performance Improvement Council, determine its agenda, direct its work, and establish and direct subgroups of the Performance Improvement Council, as appropriate, to deal with particular subject matters;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc690df-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/2/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> assist the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to improve the performance of the Federal Government and achieve the Federal Government priority goals;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc900e0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/2/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> assist the Director of the Office of Management and Budget in implementing the planning, reporting, and use of performance information requirements related to the Federal Government priority goals provided under sections 1115, 1120, 1121, and 1122 of this title;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc900e1-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/2/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> work to resolve specific Governmentwide or crosscutting performance issues, as necessary;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc900e2-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/2/E"><span itemtype="num" value="E">(E)</span></p> facilitate the exchange among agencies of practices that have led to performance improvements within specific programs, agencies, or across agencies;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc900e3-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/2/F"><span itemtype="num" value="F">(F)</span></p> coordinate with other interagency management councils;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc900e4-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/2/G"><span itemtype="num" value="G">(G)</span></p> seek advice and information as appropriate from nonmember agencies, particularly smaller agencies;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc900e5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/2/H"><span itemtype="num" value="H">(H)</span></p> consider the performance improvement experiences of corporations, nonprofit organizations, foreign, State, and local governments, Government employees, public sector unions, and customers of Government services;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc900e6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/2/I"><span itemtype="num" value="I">(I)</span></p> receive such assistance, information and advice from agencies as the Council may request, which agencies shall provide to the extent permitted by law; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc900e7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/2/J"><span itemtype="num" value="J">(J)</span></p> develop and submit to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, or when appropriate to the President through the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, at times and in such formats as the chairperson may specify, recommendations to streamline and improve performance management policies and requirements.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id0fc900e8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Support.—</span></p><p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc900e9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/3/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">In general</span>.—</span></p>The Administrator of General Services shall provide administrative and other support for the Council to implement this section.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id0fc900ea-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1124/b/3/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Personnel</span>.—</span></p>The heads of agencies with Performance Improvement Officers serving on the Council shall, as appropriate and to the extent permitted by law, provide at the request of the chairperson of the Performance Improvement Council up to 2 personnel authorizations to serve at the direction of the chairperson.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(Added <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/111/352">Pub. L. 111–352</span>, § 9, <span itemtype="date" date="2011-01-04">Jan. 4, 2011</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/124/3878">124 Stat. 3878</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id0fc900ec-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s1125"><span itemtype="num" value="1125">§ 1125.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Elimination of unnecessary agency
