itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df960-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/4/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Order of issuance</span>.—</span></p>The quarter dollar coins issued under this subsection bearing designs of national sites shall be issued in the order in which the sites selected under paragraph (3) were first established as a national site.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df961-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/4/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Rate of issuance</span>.—</span></p>The quarter dollar coins bearing designs of national sites under this subsection shall be issued at the rate of 5 new designs during each year of the period of issuance under this subsection.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df962-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/4/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Number of each of 5 coin designs in each year</span>.—</span></p>Of the quarter dollar coins issued during each year of the period of issuance, the Secretary of the Treasury shall prescribe, on the basis of such factors as the Secretary determines to be appropriate, the number of quarter dollars which shall be issued with each of the designs selected for such year.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df963-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Treatment as numismatic items</span>.—</span></p>For purposes of sections 5134 and 5136, all coins minted under this subsection shall be considered to be numismatic items.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df964-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/6"><span itemtype="num" value="6">(6)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Issuance.—</span></p><p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df965-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/6/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Quality of coins</span>.—</span></p>The Secretary may mint and issue such number of quarter dollars of each design selected under paragraph (3) in uncirculated and proof qualities as the Secretary determines to be appropriate.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df966-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/6/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Silver coins</span>.—</span></p>Notwithstanding subsection (b), the Secretary may mint and issue such number of quarter dollars of each design selected under paragraph (3) as the Secretary determines to be appropriate, with a content of not less than 90 percent silver.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df967-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/7"><span itemtype="num" value="7">(7)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Period of issuance.—</span></p><p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df968-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/7/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">In general</span>.—</span></p>Subject to paragraph (2), the program established under this subsection shall continue in effect until a national site in each State has been honored.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df969-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/7/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Second round at discretion of secretary.—</span></p><p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I14" class="indent3" id="id100df96a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/7/B/i"><span itemtype="num" value="i">(i)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Determination</span>.—</span></p>The Secretary may make a determination before the end of the 9-year period beginning when the first quarter dollar is issued under this subsection to continue the period of issuance until a second national site in each State, the District of Columbia, and each territory referred to in this subsection has been honored with a design on a quarter dollar.<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I14" class="indent3" id="id100df96b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/7/B/ii"><span itemtype="num" value="ii">(ii)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Notice and report</span>.—</span></p>Within 30 days after making a determination under clause (i), the Secretary shall submit a written report on such determination to the Committee on Financial Services of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs of the Senate.<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I14" class="indent3" id="id100df96c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/7/B/iii"><span itemtype="num" value="iii">(iii)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Applicability of provisions</span>.—</span></p>If the Secretary makes a determination under clause (i), the provisions of this subsection applicable to site and design selection and approval, the order, timing, and conditions of issuance shall apply in like manner as the initial issuance of quarter dollars under this subsection, except that the issuance of quarter dollars pursuant to such determination bearing the first design shall commence in order immediately following the last issuance of quarter dollars under the first round.<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I14" class="indent3" id="id100df96d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/7/B/iv"><span itemtype="num" value="iv">(iv)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Continuation until all states are honored</span>.—</span></p>If the Secretary makes a determination under clause (i), the program under this subsection shall continue until a second site in each State has been so honored.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df96e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/8"><span itemtype="num" value="8">(8)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Designs after end of program</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>Upon the completion of the coin program under this subsection, the design on—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df96f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/8/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> the obverse of the quarter dollar shall revert to the same design containing an image of President Washington in effect for the quarter dollar before the institution of the 50-State quarter dollar program; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df970-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/8/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> notwithstanding the fourth sentence of subsection (d)(1), the reverse of the quarter dollar shall contain an image of General Washington crossing the Delaware River prior to the Battle of Trenton.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df971-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/9"><span itemtype="num" value="9">(9)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">National site</span>.—</span></p>For purposes of this subsection, the term “national site” means any site under the supervision, management, or conservancy of the National Park Service, the United States Forest Service, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, or any similar department or agency of the Federal Government, including any national park, national monument, national battlefield, national military park, national historical park, national historic site, national lakeshore, seashore, recreation area, parkway, scenic river, or trail and any site in the National Wildlife Refuge System.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df972-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/t/10"><span itemtype="num" value="10">(10)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Application in event of independence</span>.—</span></p>If any territory becomes independent or otherwise ceases to be a territory or possession of the United States before quarter dollars bearing designs which are emblematic of such territory are minted pursuant to this subsection, this subsection shall cease to apply with respect to such territory.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id100df973-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/u"><span itemtype="num" value="u">(u)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Silver Bullion Investment Product.—</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df974-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/u/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">In general</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>The Secretary shall strike and make available for sale such number of bullion coins as the Secretary determines to be appropriate that are likenesses of the quarter dollars issued under subsection (t), each of which shall—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df975-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/u/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> have a diameter determined by the Secretary that is no less than 2.5 inches and no greater than 3.0 inches and weigh 5.0 ounces;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df976-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/u/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> contain .999 fine silver;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df977-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/u/1/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> bear an inscription of the denomination of such coin, which shall be “quarter dollar”; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df978-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/u/1/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> not be minted or issued by the United States Mint as so-called “fractional” bullion coins or in any size other than the size described in paragraph (A).<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df979-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/u/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Availability for sale</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>Bullion coins minted under paragraph (1)—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df97a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/u/2/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> shall become available for sale no sooner than the first day of the calendar year in which the circulating quarter dollar of which such bullion coin is a duplicate is issued; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df97b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/u/2/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> may only be available for sale during the year in which such circulating quarter dollar is issued.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df97c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/u/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Distribution.—</span></p><p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df97d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/u/3/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">In general</span>.—</span></p>In addition to the authorized dealers utilized by the Secretary in distributing bullion coins and solely for purposes of distributing bullion coins issued under this subsection, the Director of the National Park Service, or the designee of the Director, may purchase numismatic items issued under this subsection, but only in units of no fewer than 1,000 at a time, and the Director, or the Director’s designee, may resell or repackage such numismatic items as the Director determines to be appropriate.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df97e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/u/3/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Resale</span>.—</span></p>The Director of the National Park Service, or the designee of the Director, may resell, at cost and without repackaging, numismatic items acquired by the Director or such designee under subparagraph (A) to any party affiliated with any national site honored by a quarter dollar under subsection (t) for repackaging and resale by such party in the same manner and to the same extent as such party would be authorized to engage in such activities under subparagraph (A) if the party were acting as the designee of the Director under such subparagraph.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id100df97f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v"><span itemtype="num" value="v">(v)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Palladium Bullion Investment Coins.—</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df980-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">In general</span>.—</span></p>The Secretary shall mint and issue the palladium coins described in paragraph (12) of subsection (a) in such quantities as the Secretary may determine to be appropriate to meet demand.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df981-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Source of bullion.—</span></p><p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df982-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v/2/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">In general</span>.—</span></p>To the greatest extent possible, the Secretary shall acquire bullion for the palladium coins issued under this subsection by purchase of palladium mined from natural deposits in the United States, or in a territory or possession of the United States, within 1 year after the month in which the ore from which it is derived was mined. If no such palladium is available or if it is not economically feasible to obtain such palladium, the Secretary may obtain palladium for the palladium coins described in paragraph (12) of subsection (a) from other available sources.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df983-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v/2/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Price of bullion</span>.—</span></p>The Secretary shall pay not more than the average world price for the palladium under subparagraph (A).<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df984-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Sale of coins</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>Each coin issued under this subsection shall be sold for an amount the Secretary determines to be appropriate, but not less than the sum of—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df985-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v/3/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> the market value of the bullion at the time of sale; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df986-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v/3/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> the cost of designing and issuing the coins, including labor, materials, dies, use of machinery, overhead expenses, marketing, distribution, and shipping.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df987-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Treatment</span>.—</span></p>For purposes of section 5134 and 5136, all coins minted under this subsection shall be considered to be numismatic items.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df988-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v/5"><span itemtype="num" value="5">(5)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Quality</span>.—</span></p>The Secretary may issue collectible versions of the coins described in paragraph (1) in both proof and uncirculated versions, except that, should the Secretary determine that it is appropriate to issue proof or uncirculated versions of such coin, the Secretary shall, to the greatest extent possible, ensure that the surface treatment of each year’s proof or uncirculated version differs in some material way from that of the preceding year.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df989-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v/6"><span itemtype="num" value="6">(6)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Design</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>Coins minted and issued under this subsection shall bear designs on the obverse and reverse that are close likenesses of the work of famed American coin designer and medallic artist Adolph Alexander Weinman—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df98a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v/6/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> the obverse shall bear a high-relief likeness of the “Winged Liberty” design used on the obverse of the so-called “Mercury dime”;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df98b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v/6/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> the reverse shall bear a high-relief version of the reverse design of the 1907 American Institute of Architects medal; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id100df98c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v/6/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> the coin shall bear such other inscriptions, including “Liberty”, “In God We Trust”, “United States of America”, the denomination and weight of the coin and the fineness of the metal, as the Secretary determines to be appropriate and in keeping with the original design.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id100df98d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5112/v/7"><span itemtype="num" value="7">(7)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Mint facility</span>.—</span></p>Any United States mint, other than the United States Mint at West Point, New York, may be used to strike coins minted under this subsection other than any proof version of any such coin. If the Secretary determines that it is appropriate to issue any proof version of such coin, coins of such version shall be struck only at the United States Mint at West Point, New York.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/981">96 Stat. 981</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/452">Pub. D, title VI</span>, § 616, <span itemtype="date" date="2009-03-11">Mar. 11, 2009</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/123/677">123 Stat. 677</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/111/302">Pub. L. 111–302</span>, §§ 4, 5, <span itemtype="date" date="2010-12-14">Dec. 14, 2010</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/124/3273">124 Stat. 3273</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/111/303">Pub. L. 111–303</span>, § 2, <span itemtype="date" date="2010-12-14">Dec. 14, 2010</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/124/3275">124 Stat. 3275</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/114/94/dG/tLXXIII">Pub. L. 114–94, div. G, title LXXIII</span>, § 73001(1), <span itemtype="date" date="2015-12-04">Dec. 4, 2015</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/129/1785">129 Stat. 1785</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id1012daad-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5113"><span itemtype="num" value="5113">§ 5113.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Tolerances and testing of coins</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id1012daae-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5113/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p> The Secretary of the Treasury may prescribe reasonable manufacturing tolerances for specifications in <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s5112"/>section 5112 of this title (except for specifications that are limits) for the dollar, half dollar, quarter dollar, and dime coins. The weight of the 5-cent coin may vary not more than 0.194 gram. The weight of the one-cent coin may vary not more than 0.13 gram. Any gold coin issued under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s5112"/>section 5112 of this title shall contain the full weight of gold stated on the coin.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id1012daaf-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5113/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Secretary shall keep a record of the kind, number, and weight of each group of coins minted and test a number of the coins separately to determine if the coins conform to the weight specified in <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s5112/a">section 5112(a) of this title</span>. If the coins tested do not conform, the Secretary—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id1012dab0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5113/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> shall weigh each coin of the group separately and deface the coins that do not conform and cast them into bars for reminting; or<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id1012dab1-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5113/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> may remelt the group of coins.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/983">96 Stat. 983</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/100/274">Pub. L. 100–274</span>, § 4(b), <span itemtype="date" date="1988-03-31">Mar. 31, 1988</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/102/50">102 Stat. 50</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id1012dab6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5114"><span itemtype="num" value="5114">§ 5114.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Engraving and printing currency and security documents</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id1012dab7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5114/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span><span itemtype="heading"> Authority To Engrave and Print.—</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id1012dab8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5114/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">In general</span>.—</span></p>The Secretary of the Treasury shall engrave and print United States currency and bonds of the United States Government and currency and bonds of United States territories and possessions from intaglio plates on plate printing presses the Secretary selects. However, other security documents and checks may be printed by any process the Secretary selects. Engraving and printing shall be carried out within the Department of the Treasury if the Secretary decides the engraving and printing can be carried out as cheaply, perfectly, and safely as outside the Department.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id1012dab9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5114/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Engraving and printing for other governments</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>The Secretary of the Treasury may produce currency, postage stamps, and other security documents for foreign governments if—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id1012daba-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5114/a/2/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> the Secretary of the Treasury determines that such production will not interfere with engraving and printing needs of the United States; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id1012dabb-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5114/a/2/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> the Secretary of State determines that such production would be consistent with the foreign policy of the United States.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id1012dabc-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5114/a/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Procurement guidelines</span>.—</span></p>Articles, material, and supplies procured for use in the production of currency, postage stamps, and other security documents for foreign governments pursuant to paragraph (2) shall be treated in the same manner as articles, material, and supplies procured for public use within the United States for purposes of title III of the Act of <p itemtype="date" date="1933-03-03"/>March 3, 1933 (<p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t41/s10a"/>41 U.S.C. 10a et seq.; commonly referred to as the Buy American Act).<p itemtype="ref" class="footnoteRef" idref="fn002073"/>1<p itemtype="note" type="footnote" id="fn002073"><span itemtype="num">1</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id1012dabd-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5114/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p> United States currency has the inscription “In God We Trust” in a place the Secretary decides is appropriate. Only the portrait of a deceased individual may appear on United States currency and securities. The name of the individual shall be inscribed below the portrait.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524ae-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5114/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Secretary may make a contract to manufacture distinctive paper for United States currency and securities. To promote competition among manufacturers of the distinctive paper, the Secretary may split the award for the manufacture of the paper between the 2 bidders with the lowest prices a pound. When the Secretary decides that it is necessary to operate more than one mill to manufacture distinctive paper, the Secretary may—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524af-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5114/c/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> employ individuals temporarily at rates of pay equivalent to the rates of pay of regular employees; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524b0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5114/c/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> charge the pay of the temporary employees to the appropriation available for manufacturing distinctive paper.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/983">96 Stat. 983</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/108/458/tVI">Pub. L. 108–458, title VI</span>, § 6301(a), <span itemtype="date" date="2004-12-17">Dec. 17, 2004</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/118/3748">118 Stat. 3748</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/112/74/dC/tI">Pub. L. 112–74, div. C, title I</span>, § 116, <span itemtype="date" date="2011-12-23">Dec. 23, 2011</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/125/891">125 Stat. 891</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id101524b7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5115"><span itemtype="num" value="5115">§ 5115.</span><span itemtype="heading"> United States currency notes</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524b8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5115/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Secretary of the Treasury may issue United States currency notes. The notes—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524b9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5115/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> are payable to bearer; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524ba-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5115/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> shall be in a form and in denominations of at least one dollar that the Secretary prescribes.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524bb-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5115/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The amount of United States currency notes outstanding and in circulation—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524bc-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5115/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> may not be more than $300,000,000; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524bd-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5115/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> may not be held or used for a reserve.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/983">96 Stat. 983</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id101524c1-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5116"><span itemtype="num" value="5116">§ 5116.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Buying and selling gold and silver</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524c2-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5116/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524c3-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5116/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> With the approval of the President, the Secretary of the Treasury may—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524c4-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5116/a/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> buy and sell gold in the way, in amounts, at rates, and on conditions the Secretary considers most advantageous to the public interest; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524c5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5116/a/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> buy the gold with any direct obligations of the United States Government or United States coins and currency authorized by law, or with amounts in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524c6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5116/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> Amounts received from the purchase of gold are an asset of the general fund of the Treasury. Amounts received from the sale of gold shall be deposited by the Secretary in the general fund of the Treasury and shall be used for the sole purpose of reducing the national debt.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524c7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5116/a/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> The Secretary shall acquire gold for the coins issued under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s5112/i"/>section 5112(i) of this title by purchase of gold mined from natural deposits in the United States, or in a territory or possession of the United States, within one year after the month in which the ore from which it is derived was mined. The Secretary shall pay not more than the average world price for the gold. In the absence of available supplies of such gold at the average world price, the Secretary may use gold from reserves held by the United States to mint the coins issued under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s5112/i"/>section 5112(i) of this title. The Secretary shall issue such regulations as may be necessary to carry out this paragraph.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524c8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5116/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524c9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5116/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> The Secretary may buy silver mined from natural deposits in the United States, or in a territory or possession of the United States, that is brought to a United States mint or assay office within one year after the month in which the ore from which it is derived was mined. The Secretary may use the coinage metal fund under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s5111/b"/>section 5111(b) of this title to buy silver under this subsection.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524ca-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5116/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> The Secretary may sell or use Government silver to mint coins, except silver transferred to stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act (<p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t50/s98"/>50 U.S.C. 98 et seq.). The Secretary shall obtain the silver for the coins authorized under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s5112/e"/>section 5112(e) of this title by purchase from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act (<p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t50/s98"/>50 U.S.C. 98 et seq.). At such time as the silver stockpile is depleted, the Secretary shall obtain silver as described in paragraph (1) to mint coins authorized under section 5112(e). If it is not economically feasible to obtain such silver, the Secretary may obtain silver for coins authorized under section 5112(e) from other available sources. The Secretary shall not pay more than the average world price for silver under any circumstances. As used in this paragraph, the term “average world price” means the price determined by a widely recognized commodity exchange at the time the silver is obtained by the Secretary. The Secretary shall sell silver under conditions the Secretary considers appropriate for at least $1.292929292 a fine troy ounce.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/984">96 Stat. 984</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/99/61/tII">Pub. L. 99–61, title II</span>, § 203, <span itemtype="date" date="1985-07-09">July 9, 1985</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/99/116">99 Stat. 116</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/99/185">Pub. L. 99–185</span>, § 2(c), <span itemtype="date" date="1985-12-17">Dec. 17, 1985</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/99/1178">99 Stat. 1178</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/100/274">Pub. L. 100–274</span>, § 5, <span itemtype="date" date="1988-03-31">Mar. 31, 1988</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/102/50">102 Stat. 50</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/107/201">Pub. L. 107–201</span>, § 3(a)(1), <span itemtype="date" date="2002-07-23">July 23, 2002</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/116/737">116 Stat. 737</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id101524d5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5117"><span itemtype="num" value="5117">§ 5117.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Transferring gold and gold certificates</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524d6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5117/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p> All right, title, and interest, and every claim of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, a Federal reserve bank, and a Federal reserve agent, in and to gold is transferred to and vests in the United States Government to be held in the Treasury. Payment for the transferred gold is made by crediting equivalent amounts in dollars in accounts established in the Treasury under the 15th paragraph of section 16 of the Federal Reserve Act (<p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t12/s467"/>12 U.S.C. 467). Gold not in the possession of the Government shall be held in custody for the Government and delivered on the order of the Secretary of the Treasury. The Board of Governors, Federal reserve banks, and Federal reserve agents shall give instructions and take action necessary to ensure that the gold is so held and delivered.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524d7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5117/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p> The Secretary shall issue gold certificates against gold transferred under subsection (a) of this section. The Secretary may issue gold certificates against other gold held in the Treasury. The Secretary may prescribe the form and denominations of the certificates. The amount of outstanding certificates may be not more than the value (for the purpose of issuing those certificates, of 42 and two-ninths dollars a fine troy ounce) of the gold held against gold certificates. The Secretary shall hold gold in the Treasury equal to the required dollar amount as security for gold certificates issued after <p itemtype="date" date="1934-01-29"/>January 29, 1934.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524d8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5117/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p> With the approval of the President, the Secretary may prescribe regulations the Secretary considers necessary to carry out this section.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/984">96 Stat. 984</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id101524dc-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118"><span itemtype="num" value="5118">§ 5118.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Gold clauses and consent to sue</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524dd-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> In this section—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524de-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> “gold clause” means a provision in or related to an obligation alleging to give the obligee a right to require payment in—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id101524df-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/a/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> gold;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id101524e0-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/a/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> a particular United States coin or currency; or<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I13" class="indent2" id="id101524e1-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/a/1/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> United States money measured in gold or a particular United States coin or currency.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524e2-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> “public debt obligation” means a domestic obligation issued or guaranteed by the United States Government to repay money or interest.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524e3-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p> The United States Government may not pay out any gold coin. A person lawfully holding United States coins and currency may present the coins and currency to the Secretary of the Treasury for exchange (dollar for dollar) for other United States coins and currency (other than gold and silver coins) that may be lawfully held. The Secretary shall make the exchange under regulations prescribed by the Secretary.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524e4-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524e5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/c/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Government withdraws its consent given to anyone to assert against the Government, its agencies, or its officers, employees, or agents, a claim—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524e6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/c/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> on a gold clause public debt obligation or interest on the obligation;<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524e7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/c/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> for United States coins or currency; or<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524e8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/c/1/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> arising out of the surrender, requisition, seizure, or acquisition of United States coins or currency, gold, or silver involving the effect or validity of a change in the metallic content of the dollar or in a regulation about the value of money.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524e9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/c/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not apply to a proceeding in which no claim is made for payment or credit in an amount greater than the face or nominal value in dollars of public debt obligations or United States coins or currency involved in the proceeding.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524ea-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/c/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> Except when consent is not withdrawn under this subsection, an amount appropriated for payment on public debt obligations and for United States coins and currency may be expended only dollar for dollar.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524eb-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/d"><span itemtype="num" value="d">(d)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524ec-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/d/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> In this subsection, “obligation” means any obligation (except United States currency) payable in United States money.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524ed-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5118/d/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> An obligation issued containing a gold clause or governed by a gold clause is discharged on payment (dollar for dollar) in United States coin or currency that is legal tender at the time of payment. This paragraph does not apply to an obligation issued after <p itemtype="date" date="1977-10-27"/>October 27, 1977.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/985">96 Stat. 985</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/99/185">Pub. L. 99–185</span>, § 2(d), <span itemtype="date" date="1985-12-17">Dec. 17, 1985</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/99/1178">99 Stat. 1178</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/104/208/dA/tII">Pub. L. 104–208, div. A, title II</span>, § 2609, <span itemtype="date" date="1996-09-30">Sept. 30, 1996</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/110/3009-475">110 Stat. 3009–475</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/105/61/tVI">Pub. L. 105–61, title VI</span>, § 641, <span itemtype="date" date="1997-10-10">Oct. 10, 1997</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/111/1318">111 Stat. 1318</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id101524f4-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119"><span itemtype="num" value="5119">§ 5119.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Redemption and cancellation of currency</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524f5-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p> Except to the extent authorized in regulations the Secretary of the Treasury prescribes with the approval of the President, the Secretary may not redeem United States currency (including Federal reserve notes and circulating notes of Federal reserve banks and national banks) in gold. However, the Secretary shall redeem gold certificates owned by the Federal reserve banks at times and in amounts the Secretary decides are necessary to maintain the equal purchasing power of each kind of United States currency. When redemption in gold is authorized, the redemption may be made only in gold bullion bearing the stamp of a United States mint or assay office in an amount equal at the time of redemption to the currency presented for redemption.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524f6-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524f7-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> Except as provided in subsection (c)(1) of this section, the following are public debts bearing no interest:<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524f8-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/b/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> gold certificates issued before <p itemtype="date" date="1934-01-30"/>January 30, 1934.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524f9-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/b/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> silver certificates.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524fa-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/b/1/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> notes issued under the Act of <p itemtype="date" date="1890-07-14"/>July 14, 1890 (ch. 708, <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/26/289"/>26 Stat. 289).<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524fb-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/b/1/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> Federal Reserve notes for which payment was made under section 4 of the Old Series Currency Adjustment Act.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524fc-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/b/1/E"><span itemtype="num" value="E">(E)</span></p> United States currency notes, including those issued under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/act/1862-02-25/s1"/>section 1 of the Act of February 25, 1862 (ch. 33, <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/12/345"/>12 Stat. 345), the Act of <p itemtype="date" date="1862-07-11"/>July 11, 1862 (ch. 142, <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/12/532"/>12 Stat. 532), the resolution of <p itemtype="date" date="1863-01-17"/>January 17, 1863 (P.R. 9; <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/12/822"/>12 Stat. 822), <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/act/1863-03-03/s2"/>section 2 of the Act of March 3, 1863 (ch. 73, <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/12/710"/>12 Stat. 710), or <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s5115"/>section 5115 of this title.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id101524fd-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span><span itemtype="heading"> <span itemtype="inline" class="small-caps">Redemption, cancellation, and destruction of currency</span>.—</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/>The Secretary shall—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524fe-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/b/2/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> redeem any currency described in paragraph (1) from the general fund of the Treasury upon presentment to the Secretary; and<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id101524ff-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/b/2/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> cancel and destroy such currency upon redemption.<p itemtype="continuation" style="-uslm-lc:I10" class="indent0 firstIndent0"/>The Secretary shall not be required to reissue United States currency notes upon redemption.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10152500-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10152501-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/c/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Secretary may determine the amount of the following United States currency that will not be presented for redemption because the currency has been destroyed or irretrievably lost:<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10152502-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/c/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> circulating notes of Federal reserve banks and national banks issued before <p itemtype="date" date="1929-07-01"/>July 1, 1929, for which the United States Government has assumed liability.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10152503-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/c/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> outstanding currency referred to in subsection (b)(1) of this section.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10152504-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/c/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> When the Secretary makes a determination under this subsection, the Secretary shall reduce the amount of that currency outstanding by the amount the Secretary determines will not be redeemed and credit the appropriate receipt account.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10152505-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5119/d"><span itemtype="num" value="d">(d)</span></p> To provide a historical collection of United States currency, the Secretary may withhold from cancellation and destruction and transfer to a special account one piece of each design, issue, or series of each denomination of each kind of currency (including circulating notes of Federal reserve banks and national banks) after redemption. The Secretary may make appropriate entries in Treasury accounts because of the transfers.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/985">96 Stat. 985</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/102/390/tII">Pub. L. 102–390, title II</span>, § 226(b), <span itemtype="date" date="1992-10-06">Oct. 6, 1992</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/106/1630">106 Stat. 1630</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/103/325/tVI">Pub. L. 103–325, title VI</span>, § 602(g)(14), <span itemtype="date" date="1994-09-23">Sept. 23, 1994</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/108/2294">108 Stat. 2294</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id1017960b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5120"><span itemtype="num" value="5120">§ 5120.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Obsolete, mutilated, and worn coins and currency</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id1017960c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5120/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id1017960d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5120/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Secretary of the Treasury shall melt obsolete and worn United States coins withdrawn from circulation. The Secretary may use the metal from melting the coins for reminting or may sell the metal. The Secretary shall account for the following in the coinage metal fund under <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s5111/b">section 5111(b) of this title</span>:<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id1017960e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5120/a/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> obsolete and worn coins and the metal from melting the coins.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id1017960f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5120/a/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> proceeds from the sale of the metal.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179610-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5120/a/1/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p> losses incurred in the sale of the metal.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179611-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5120/a/1/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> losses incurred because of the difference between the face value of the coins melted and the coins minted from the metal.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179612-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5120/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> The Secretary shall reimburse the coinage metal fund for losses under paragraph (1)(C) and (D) of this subsection out of amounts in the coinage profit fund under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s5111/b"/>section 5111(b) of this title.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179613-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5120/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Secretary shall—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179614-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5120/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> cancel and destroy (by a secure process) obsolete, mutilated, and worn United States currency withdrawn from circulation; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179615-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5120/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> dispose of the residue of the currency and notes.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179616-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5120/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p> The Comptroller General shall audit the cancellation and destruction of United States currency and the accounting of the cancellation and destruction. Records the Comptroller General considers necessary to make an effective audit easier shall be made available to the Comptroller General.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/986">96 Stat. 986</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id1017961c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5121"><span itemtype="num" value="5121">§ 5121.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Refining, assaying, and valuation of bullion</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id1017961d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5121/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Secretary of the Treasury shall—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id1017961e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5121/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> melt and refine bullion;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id1017961f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5121/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> as required, assay coins, metal, and bullion;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179620-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5121/a/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> cast gold and silver bullion deposits into bars; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179621-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5121/a/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> cast alloys into bars for minting coins.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179622-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5121/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p> A person owning gold or silver bullion may deposit the bullion with the Secretary to be cast into fine, standard fineness, or unrefined bars weighing at least 5 troy ounces. When practicable, the Secretary shall weigh the bullion in front of the depositor. The Secretary shall give the depositor a receipt for the bullion stating the description and weight of the bullion. When the Secretary has to melt the bullion or remove base metals before the value of the bullion can be determined, the weight is the weight after the melting or removal of the metals. The Secretary may refuse a deposit of gold bullion if the deposit is less than $100 in value or the bullion is so base that it is unsuitable for the operations of the Bureau of the Mint.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179623-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5121/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p> When the gold and silver are combined in bullion that is deposited and either the gold or silver is so little that it cannot be separated economically, the Secretary may not pay the depositor for the gold or silver that cannot be separated.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179624-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5121/d"><span itemtype="num" value="d">(d)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179625-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5121/d/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> Under conditions prescribed by the Secretary, a person may exchange unrefined bullion for fine bars when—<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179626-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5121/d/1/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> gold and silver are combined in the bullion in proportions that cannot be economically refined; or<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179627-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5121/d/1/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p> necessary supplies of acids cannot be procured at reasonable rates.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179628-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5121/d/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> The charge for refining in an exchange under this subsection may be not more than the charge imposed in an exchange of unrefined bullion for refined bullion.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179629-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5121/e"><span itemtype="num" value="e">(e)</span></p> The Secretary shall prepare bars for payment of deposits. The Secretary shall stamp each bar with a designation of the weight and fineness of the bar and a symbol the Secretary considers suitable to prevent fraudulent imitation of the bar.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/987">96 Stat. 987</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id1017962e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5122"><span itemtype="num" value="5122">§ 5122.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Payment to depositors</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id1017962f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5122/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p> The Secretary of the Treasury shall determine the fineness, weight, and value of each deposit and bar under <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s5121"/>section 5121 of this title. The value and the amount of charges under subsection (b) of this section shall be based on the fineness and weight of the bullion. The Secretary shall give the depositor a statement of the charges and the net amount of the deposit to be paid in money or bars of the same species of bullion as that deposited.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179630-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5122/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The Secretary shall impose a charge equal to the average cost of material, labor, waste, and use of machinery of a United States mint or assay office for—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179631-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5122/b/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> melting and refining bullion;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179632-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5122/b/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> using copper as an alloy when bullion deposited is above standard;<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179633-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5122/b/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> separating gold and silver combined in the bullion; and<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179634-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5122/b/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> preparing bars.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179635-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5122/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p> The Secretary shall pay to the depositor or to a person designated by the depositor money or bars equivalent to the bullion deposited as soon as practicable after the value of the deposit is determined. If demanded, the Secretary shall pay depositors in the order in which the bullion is deposited with the Secretary. However, when there is an unavoidable delay in determining the value of a deposit, the Secretary shall pay subsequent depositors. When practicable and convenient, the Secretary shall pay depositors in the denominations requested by the depositor. After the depositor is paid, the bullion is the property of the United States Government.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179636-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5122/d"><span itemtype="num" value="d">(d)</span></p> To allow the Secretary to pay depositors with as little delay as possible, the Secretary shall keep in the mints and assay offices, when possible, money and bullion the Secretary decides are convenient and necessary.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/987">96 Stat. 987</span>.)</p><p itemtype="subchapter" style="-uslm-lc:I81" id="id1017963a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/stIV/ch51/schIII"><span itemtype="num" value="III">SUBCHAPTER III—</span><span itemtype="heading">UNITED STATES MINT</span></p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id1017963d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5131"><span itemtype="num" value="5131">§ 5131.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Organization</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id1017963e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5131/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> The United States Mint has—<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id1017963f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5131/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> a United States mint at Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179640-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5131/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p> a United States mint at Denver, Colorado.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179641-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5131/a/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> a United States mint at West Point, New York.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179642-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5131/a/4"><span itemtype="num" value="4">(4)</span></p> a United States mint at San Francisco, California.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179643-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5131/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p> The Secretary of the Treasury shall carry out duties and powers related to refining and assaying bullion, minting coins, striking medals, and numismatic items at the mints. However, until the Secretary decides that the mints are adequate for minting and striking an ample supply of coins and medals, the Secretary may use any facility of the United States Mint to mint coins and strike medals and to store coins and medals.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179644-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5131/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p> Laws on mints, officers and employees of mints, and punishment of offenses related to mints and minting coins apply to assay offices, as applicable.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/988">96 Stat. 988</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/100/274">Pub. L. 100–274</span>, § 2(a)–(c)(2), <span itemtype="date" date="1988-03-31">Mar. 31, 1988</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/102/48">102 Stat. 48</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/102/390/tII">Pub. L. 102–390, title II</span>, §§ 224, 225(b)(3), (4), <span itemtype="date" date="1992-10-06">Oct. 6, 1992</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/106/1629">106 Stat. 1629</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/104/208/dA/tI">Pub. L. 104–208, div. A, title I</span>, § 101(f) [title V, §§ 503, 522], <span itemtype="date" date="1996-09-30">Sept. 30, 1996</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/110/3009-314">110 Stat. 3009–314</span>, 3009–344, 3009–347; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/104/329/tIII">Pub. L. 104–329, title III</span>, § 304, <span itemtype="date" date="1996-10-20">Oct. 20, 1996</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/110/4015">110 Stat. 4015</span>.)</p><p itemtype="section" style="-uslm-lc:I80" id="id1017964a-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132"><span itemtype="num" value="5132">§ 5132.</span><span itemtype="heading"> Administrative</span></p><p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id1017964b-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132/a"><span itemtype="num" value="a">(a)</span></p><p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id1017964c-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132/a/1"><span itemtype="num" value="1">(1)</span></p> Except as provided in this chapter, the Secretary of the Treasury shall deposit in the Treasury as miscellaneous receipts amounts the Secretary receives from the operations of the United States Mint. Expenditures made from appropriated funds which are subsequently determined to be properly chargeable to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund established by section 5134 shall be reimbursed by such Fund to the appropriation. The Secretary shall annually sell to the public, directly and by mail, sets of uncirculated and proof coins minted under paragraphs (1) through (6) of <p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t31/s5112/a"/>section 5112(a) of this title, and shall solicit such sales through the use of the customer list of the United States Mint. Except with respect to amounts deposited in the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund in accordance with section 5134, the Secretary may not use amounts the Secretary receives from profits on minting coins or from charges on gold or silver bullion under section 5122 to pay officers and employees.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id1017964d-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132/a/2"><span itemtype="num" value="2">(2)</span></p><p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id1017964e-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132/a/2/A"><span itemtype="num" value="A">(A)</span></p> In addition to the coins described in paragraph (1), the Secretary shall sell annually to the public directly and by mail, sets of proof coins minted under paragraphs (1) through (6) of section 5112(a).<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id1017964f-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132/a/2/B"><span itemtype="num" value="B">(B)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> Notwithstanding any other provision of law, for purposes of this paragraph—<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179650-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132/a/2/B/i"><span itemtype="num" value="i">(i)</span></p> the coins described in paragraphs (2) through (4) of section 5112(a) shall be made of an alloy of not less than 90 percent silver; and<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179651-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132/a/2/B/ii"><span itemtype="num" value="ii">(ii)</span></p> all coins minted under this paragraph shall have a mint mark indicating the place of manufacture.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179652-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132/a/2/C"><span itemtype="num" value="C">(C)</span></p><p itemtype="chapeau"/> All coins minted under this paragraph shall be considered to be—<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179653-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132/a/2/C/i"><span itemtype="num" value="i">(i)</span></p> numismatic items for purposes of paragraph (1) and section 5111(a)(3); and<p itemtype="clause" style="-uslm-lc:I12" class="indent1" id="id10179654-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132/a/2/C/ii"><span itemtype="num" value="ii">(ii)</span></p> legal tender, as provided in section 5103.<p itemtype="subparagraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179655-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132/a/2/D"><span itemtype="num" value="D">(D)</span></p> The Secretary shall obtain silver for coins minted under this paragraph by purchase from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act (<p itemtype="ref" href="/us/usc/t50/s98"/>50 U.S.C. 98 et seq.). At such time as the silver stockpile is depleted, the Secretary shall obtain silver for such coins by purchase of silver mined from natural deposits in the United States or in a territory or possession of the United States not more than 1 year following the month in which the ore from which it is derived was mined. The Secretary shall pay not more than the average world price for such silver. The Secretary may issue such regulations as may be necessary to carry out this subparagraph.<p itemtype="paragraph" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179656-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132/a/3"><span itemtype="num" value="3">(3)</span></p> Not more than $54,208,000 may be appropriated to the Secretary for the fiscal year ending on <p itemtype="date" date="1993-09-30"/>September 30, 1993, to pay costs of the mints. Not more than $965,000 of amounts appropriated pursuant to the preceding sentence shall remain available until expended for research and development.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179657-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132/b"><span itemtype="num" value="b">(b)</span></p> To the extent the Secretary decides is necessary, the Secretary may use amounts received from depositors for refining bullion and the proceeds from the sale of byproducts (including spent acids from surplus bullion recovered in refining processes) to pay the costs of refining the bullion (including labor, material, waste, and loss on the sale of sweeps). The Secretary may not use amounts appropriated for the mints to pay those costs.<p itemtype="subsection" style="-uslm-lc:I11" class="indent0" id="id10179658-4db1-11e6-8af2-b19ed7ef7a5f" identifier="/us/usc/t31/s5132/c"><span itemtype="num" value="c">(c)</span></p> The Secretary shall make an annual report at the end of each fiscal year on the operation of the United States Mint.<p itemtype="sourceCredit">(<span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/258">Pub. L. 97–258</span>, <span itemtype="date" date="1982-09-13">Sept. 13, 1982</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/988">96 Stat. 988</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/97/452">Pub. L. 97–452</span>, § 1(21), <span itemtype="date" date="1983-01-12">Jan. 12, 1983</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/96/2477">96 Stat. 2477</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/98/151">Pub. L. 98–151</span>, § 123, <span itemtype="date" date="1983-11-14">Nov. 14, 1983</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/97/979">97 Stat. 979</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/98/216">Pub. L. 98–216</span>, § 1(7), <span itemtype="date" date="1984-02-14">Feb. 14, 1984</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/98/4">98 Stat. 4</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/99/61/tII">Pub. L. 99–61, title II</span>, § 204, <span itemtype="date" date="1985-07-09">July 9, 1985</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/99/116">99 Stat. 116</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/99/185">Pub. L. 99–185</span>, § 2(e), <span itemtype="date" date="1985-12-17">Dec. 17, 1985</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/99/1178">99 Stat. 1178</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/100/274">Pub. L. 100–274</span>, §§ 1, 2(c)(3), <span itemtype="date" date="1988-03-31">Mar. 31, 1988</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/102/48">102 Stat. 48</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/101/585">Pub. L. 101–585</span>, § 2, <span itemtype="date" date="1990-11-15">Nov. 15, 1990</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/104/2874">104 Stat. 2874</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/102/390/tII">Pub. L. 102–390, title II</span>, §§ 211, 221(c)(1), 225(b)(3), (4), <span itemtype="date" date="1992-10-06">Oct. 6, 1992</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/106/1624">106 Stat. 1624</span>, 1628, 1629; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/106/445">Pub. L. 106–445</span>, § 2(a), <span itemtype="date" date="2000-11-06">Nov. 6, 2000</span>, <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/stat/114/1931">114 Stat. 1931</span>; <span itemtype="ref" href="/us/pl/114/94/dG/tLXXIII">Pub. L. 114–94, div.
